This new tutorial series explores ways to visualize data that changes over time. Topics include chart selection, forecast analysis, correlation, date patterns and more. title: Data + Sales: Bring product metrics to the sales team
summary: Sales leaders need accurate data to meet their quarterly targets. Use this guide to learn how to weave product metrics into Salesforce with Mode so they can accelerate the sales cycle. Download guide.

title: How percentile approximation works (and why it's more useful than averages)
summary:
Nice primer on percentile approximations. This post breaks down how percentiles are different than averages and shows the dangers of using averages for large time-series datasets. Includes a discussion of how percentiles work in PostgreSQL, the problems with that approach, and how percentile approximation is supported in TimescaleDB.
Timescale | David Kohn

title: Erik Bernhardsson - Former CTO @ Better.com
summary:
There's an awesome interview series on Eugene Yan's new site, ApplyingML, that focus on practical insights from the trenches. This interview with Erik Bernhardsson is a good one to start with. It's a great read with insights about ML system development, building teams, and Erik's career path in data. Follow the "Mentors" link at the top for more.
ApplyingML

title: Exploring 120 years of timezones
summary:
Timezones are a pain and that's especially true for anyone who works dates in their data. This post explores why timezones are so complex and how, over 120 years, 284 timezones evolved to what we have today.
Scott Logic | Colin Eberhardt

title: Sourcing Training Data with Mechanical Turk
summary:
Sourcing training data using Mechanical Turk isn't new, but the process described here is a clever approach that uses gamification and different types of tasks to create a more effective data collection pipeline.
New York Times R&D

title: Ace your next data science interview
summary:
Get better at data science interviews and sharpen your skills by solving a few questions per week. Join thousands of other data scientists and analysts practicing for interviews! Subscribe to our newsletter.
// sponsored

title: Awesome Data Labeling
summary:
Great collection of open-source labeling tools covering a variety of data types, including text, images, audio, time-series, and video.
GitHub | Heartex Labs

title: Business Intelligence for Modern Data Teams
summary:
Most BI tools use a drag and drop interface, which works for non-technical users but more and more, analysts want tools that enable common engineering practices, such as version control, testing, and abstraction. Evidence is a new open-source tool that uses SQL and Markdown to do all that and more.
Evidence

title: Horizon Plots for ggplot2
summary:
Horizon plots are compact versions of line charts that are particularly useful for comparing time series data across different groups. This is a great post that shows how horizon plots work and introduces a new package that makes them easy to create with ggplot2. Includes lots of code snippets and screenshots along the way.
ggHoriPlot | Iker Rivas-González

title: The ‘Great Attrition’ or the ‘Great Attraction’?
summary:
A record number of employees are quitting their jobs and that's especially true in tech. Whether you're looking for work or looking for workers, understanding what's behind all the movement will help you make smart decisions. 
McKinsey & Company

title: Leverage consumer insights data
summary: Join AWS Data Exchange and thought leaders from companies such as Acxiom and BlastPoint. They will share how organizations from retailers to auto brands are using consumer insights data to reach new customers and drive real business change.

title: Why data scientists shouldn’t need to know Kubernetes
summary:
While it may be useful to have full-stack data scientists, better tooling would help ensure that their time is well spent. In this post, Chip Huyen explores the evolving expectations of data science roles, current tools that help abstract away lower level tasks, and what's still missing.
Chip Huyen

title: Possession Is The Puzzle Of ⚽ Analytics
summary:
Great post about soccer's next big metric. Ultimately, "possession value" seeks to model the state of the game at any time and predict what that means about future rewards. For a lot of reasons, it's a non-trivial problem and there are a lot of models to choose from. Here's why.
FiveThirtyEight | John Muller

title: Gaussian processes From scratch
summary:
This first in a three part series introduces Gaussian processes and implements them from scratch using Python and NumPy. This is easy to follow with lots of visuals and code snippets along the way. For parts two and three, follow the links at the top of the post. 
Peter Roelants

title: Intro to Bayesian Methods for Media Mix Modeling
summary:
Media mix modeling is a type of analysis that helps optimize how marketing dollars are spent across multiple channels. Linear regression is commonly used but here, Michael Kaminsky introduces an approach using Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC), which can be more powerful and flexible than linear regression.
Recast | Michael Kaminsky

title: What’s An OLAP Cube?
summary:
Great introduction to OLAP cubes. Slice, dice, pivot, and hypercubes — this covers it all. And along the way you'll learn how this pattern fits with a modern data warehouse.
Claire Carroll

title: TransformX Conference: Driving AI from Experimentation to Reality
summary:
Join Scale AI for our two-day, virtual conference featuring 100+ speakers and 60+ sessions. We’re bringing together a community of leaders, visionaries, practitioners, and researchers across industries as we explore the shift from research to reality within AI and Machine Learning. Register now to secure your free ticket.
// sponsored

title: River
summary:
River is a Python package for machine learning on streaming data. Models process one observation at a time and can be updated on the fly. This is a general purpose library that handles regression, classification, and unsupervised learning.
GitHub | OnlineML

title: How Midsize Companies Can Compete in AI
summary:
Startups and multi-billion dollar giants are well-positioned to leverage AI's capabilities but mid-sized companies are being left behind. Here's how joint AI ventures can help them catch up.
Harvard Business Review

title: Understanding Bias in AI: What is it, how to identify it, and how to mitigate it.
summary: It’s no secret...bias in AI is a problem. The more powerful AI capacity becomes, the more important it becomes to ensure that we are producing tools that make life better for more people, not simply scaling and perpetuating forms of error. That’s why we’ve created a guide to understanding and addressing possible sources of bias for your AI/ML project.

title: Twelve Software Design Tips for Data Scientists
summary:
You may not need to write large programs that scale but the tips outlined here will help make sure that even small scripts are clear, easy to maintain, and designed to evolve. This is a super useful post, especially for non-engineers. For a streamlined version, see the slides.
Greg Wilson

title: A Gentle Introduction to Graph Neural Networks
summary:
Awesome introduction to graph neural networks, starting with the basics of graphs and what makes graph data different from other types of data. With lots of visualizations along the way, this post gradually explains and builds out a GNN from a bare-bones implementation to a state-of-the-art model. There's a lot to learn and play with here. 
Distill | Google Research

title: Multiplying Matrices Without Multiplying
summary:
This paper introduces a learning-based algorithm for multiplying matrices that greatly outperforms existing methods. It's important because matrix multiplication is one of the most fundamental operations in machine learning and this new approach looks FAST!
arXiv | Davis Blalock, John Guttag

title: Decision Making at Netflix
summary:
This introduction is the first in a multi-part series on how Netflix uses A/B testing to make decisions. This post lays the groundwork. Upcoming posts will cover statistical concepts, infrastructure to support and scale tests, the role of experimentation, and the importance of culture.
Netflix Tech Blog

title: TLDR Newsletter - Byte sized news for busy techies
summary:
TLDR is a daily newsletter with links and TLDRs of the most interesting stories in tech 📱, science 🚀, and coding 💻! Sign up for free today.
// sponsored

title: Recommenders
summary:
Nice collection of examples, best practices and Python utilities for building and evaluating recommendation systems.
GitHub | Microsoft

title: Python Packages
summary:
Python packages are a key part of the language that enable you to create reusable, organized, and shareable code. This open-source book shows how to build efficient workflows for creating Python packages, including package organization, testing, versioning, CI/CD, and more!
py-pkgs | Tomas Beuzen and Tiffany Timbers

title: Analyzing Geospatial Data in Python
summary:
Nice introduction to working with geospatial data using Python. Covers data types, common pitfalls, map projections, and how to work with and visualize data using the GeoPandas and Shapely libraries. 
LearnDataSci | Ioannis Prapas

title: The Modern Data Experience
summary:
A lot of "normal" people work with data these days and most don't care about the stack of tools that data practitioners use to move, store, wrangle, analyze and present data. They care about their own experience with data. "...the modern data stack isn't enough. We have to create a modern data experience." Great post!
Benn Stancil

title: Using third-party data to make smarter decisions
summary: The insights gained by using third-party data with your internal data can help you make smarter business and technical decisions. This technical eBook can help you learn how to use AWS Data Exchange to couple data sets with advanced analytics and machine learning with step-by-step instructions.

title: A lightweight data validation ecosystem
summary:
Nice approach for building an "advanced" but right-size data monitoring solution using common tools: GitHub (Actions, Pages, issues), R (pointblank + projmgr pkgs), and Slack notifications.
Emily Riederer

title: Inferring Concept Drift Without Labeled Data
summary:
A trained model might be static but because people and systems are constantly changing, models tend to drift over time. Detecting drift is key but that can be problematic with unlabeled data. This research report explores the problem and offers four ways to approach it using unsupervised methods.
Cloudera Fast Forward Labs

title: Pseudo-R²: A Metric for Quantifying Interestingness
summary:
Great post that shows how the data science team at Heap uses a statistical metric called pseudo-R² to quantify how interesting an insight will be before deciding to recommend it for analysis.
Heap | David Robinson

title: Science For People Who Give A Shit
summary:
Join tens of thousands of other smart humans and subscribe to Important, Not Important for the most vital science news of the week, deep analysis, and Action Steps you can take to 1) feel better and 2) measurably improve the world around you. Get it for free.
// sponsored

title: SQLModel
summary:
SQLModel is a library that makes it easy to interact with SQL databases from Python code. It's designed to be intuitive, highly compatible, and robust. SQLModel is based on Python type annotations and is built as a layer on top of Pydantic and SQLAlchemy.
SQLModel | Sebastián Ramírez

title: Analyzing US Census Data: Methods, Maps & Models
summary:
Kyle Walker is a spatial data science expert who specializes in population geography and demographic trends. In this new book, Kyle shows how to acquire, wrangle, visualize, and model Census data using R. This looks like a great resource and is free to read online.
Kyle Walker

title: prettymaps
summary:
pretty maps is a small Python library to draw pretty maps from OpenStreetMap data. Based on osmnx, matplotlib and shapely libraries.
GitHub | Marcelo Prates

title: Data Vis Dispatch
summary:
Datawrapper's new data visualization newsletter is a great source for curated visualizations from the media. Along with showing how data is being used to portray current events, many of the picks are good examples of visualization techniques. Sign up at the bottom of the page.
Datawrapper | Rose Mintzer-Sweeney and Lisa Charlotte Rost

title: How big data carried graph theory to new dimensions
summary:
Researchers are turning to the mathematics of higher-order interactions to better model the complex connections within their data.
Quanta Magazine | Stephen Ornes

title: Announcing TransformX Conference: Driving AI from Experimentation to Reality
summary: Join Scale AI for our two-day, virtual conference. We’re bringing together a community of leaders, visionaries, practitioners, and researchers across industries as we explore the shift from research to reality within AI and Machine Learning. 100+ speakers, 60+ sessions, 20,000+ attendees.

title: Exploring R² and regression variance with Euler/Venn diagrams
summary:
Great post that uses Euler and Venn diagrams to explain R² and shared variation in regression models. This is a very intuitive approach!
Andrew Heiss

title: ML Explained in 5 Levels of Difficulty
summary:
If you're new to the field or need a good way to explain the work you do, this is a great ML explainer video by Hilary Mason. Hilary is a well-known data scientist who has been on the founding team of several ML startups. In this video, she explains machine learning to 5 different people: a child, a teen, a college student, a grad student and an expert.
Wired | Hilary Mason

title: Nearest Neighbor Indexes for Similarity Search
summary:
Nice introduction to similarity search, including and an overview and comparison of key options.
Pinecone | James Briggs

title: Pitfalls in Machine Learning Research: Reexamining the Development Cycle
summary:
Machine learning tends to be hindered by an ad hoc design process, poor data hygiene, and a lack of statistical rigor in model evaluation. This paper explores common pitfalls, case studies, and offers practical recommendations for improvements.
arXiv | Stella Biderman, Walter J. Scheirer

title: Patterns in confusing explanations
summary:
Clear writing is a superpower but it can be a LOT of work. In this post, Julia Evans helps simplify the process by identifying common patterns of unclear writing and suggesting examples of what to do instead.
Julia Evans

title: DataCamp for Business: All you need for learning and doing data science
summary:
Measure your team’s skill gaps with timed assessments, receive personalized learning recommendations, and get them certified as professional data scientists. Assign your team custom learning tracks & let them apply their skills in our cloud-based IDE. Join over 18,000 data teams using DataCamp. Request a free demo today.
// sponsored

title: RStudio Cheatsheets
summary:
These cheatsheets for a variety of R packages have recently been updated to include the latest features. Covers dplyr, ggplot2, lubridate, forcats, reticulate, the RStudio IDE, Shiny, and stringr.
RStudio Blog | Averi Perny

title: Visualizing ordinal variables
summary:
Ordinal variables aren't numeric and they’re not categorical, which makes them hard to make sense of. This post explores why they're so tricky and ways to approach them.
Octavio Medina

title: The one data platform to rule them all... but according to whom?
summary:
Great post that breaks down a lot of the recent startups and organizes them by popular end users (e.g. data scientist, analyst, ML engineer, etc). Since a lot of the data tooling startups eventually want to become "data platforms," this post makes it easy to understand where they all fit. 
Leigh Marie Braswell

title: Data Quality Unpacked
summary:
Here's a broad look at the trends, jobs, and players of the increasingly important and complex role of data quality solutions.
Gradient Flow | Kenn So and Ben Lorica

title: Accelerate development with healthcare data
summary: Join a panel discussion with thought-leaders from AWS and healthcare powerhouse companies like QIAGEN and IBM Watson Health. Learn how healthcare datasets can accelerate the bench-to-bedside cycle through enhanced visualizations, machine learning algorithms, and curated genomics data.

title: Bootstrapping Labels
summary:
Most machine learning tutorials and papers assume the availability of training labels. But what if labeled datasets aren't available? In his latest post, Eugene Yan explores ways to generate labels from scratch using semi, active, and weakly supervised learning. There's a lot here, including examples from DoorDash, Facebook, Google, and Apple.
Eugene Yan

title: Making better decisions with statistics
summary:
To make better decisions with statistics, here are three key principles to keep in mind.
Thomas Vladeck

title: Filter data before reading with awk and R
summary:
Unix command line tools might be "old school" but you sure can do a lot with them. This tutorial shows how to use the awk utility to quickly pre-process and read lots of bigger-than-RAM csv files without crashing your computer.
Luis D. Verde Arregoitia

title: Invitation - how to make data consumable w/ AWS, Wawa, and Facebook
summary:
Join this webinar with data & analytics leaders from Wawa, AWS, and Facebook on how to make data consumable for teams, at scale. Each panelist will share strategies to help you transform cloud data into valuable insights, reduce operational complexity, and scale data access and governance across BI tools. Sign up here.
// sponsored

title: Modern Statistics with R
summary:
From wrangling and exploring data to inference and predictive modeling, this new text introduces the key parts of the modern statistical toolkit. Free to download.
Måns Thulin

title: Causal Inference for The Brave and True
summary:
This open-source book is a light-hearted yet rigorous approach to learning impact estimation and sensitivity analysis. Part 1 contains core concepts and models for causal inference. Part 2 contains modern development and applications of causal inference in industry. 
Matheus Facure Alves

title: Changes to the data science role and tools
summary:
This discussion with Sean Taylor covers a lot of ground and his insights about data science roles and how the field has evolved over the past few years is a worthwhile listen. Sean is a Data Science Manager at Lyft and was previously a research scientist at Facebook where he was key to the development of the open source forecasting library, Prophet.
Data Exchange Podcast

title: An Overview of Dataviz for Categorical Data
summary:
Categorical data is data that's bucketed into categories. Although it can be plotted using traditional chart types like line plots and scatter plots, other techniques are easier to read and are better at showing the relationships and flows between categorical data points. In this post, Jonathan Dunne explores four chart types to consider.
Nightingale | Jonathan Dunne

title: Data-Driven Album Covers
summary:
There are a few well-known album covers that feature data visualization but not many that visualize the music itself. In this post, three designers explore the mystery of finding the perfect marriage of music and image. With lots of examples.
Nightingale | Carni Klirs

title: Data Monetization With Strategic Data Assets
summary:
Most data is underutilized. To use it more effectively, companies should transform it so it can be reused and recombined to create new value.
MIT Sloan Management Review

title: Understanding Bias in AI: What is it, how to identify it, and how to mitigate it.
summary: It’s no secret...bias in AI is a problem. The more powerful AI capacity becomes, the more important it becomes to ensure that we are producing tools that make life better for more people, not simply scaling and perpetuating forms of error. That’s why we’ve created a guide to understanding and addressing possible sources of bias for your AI/ML project.

title: How Airbnb Built “Wall” to prevent data bugs
summary:
This post continues a series that explores Airbnb's massive effort to ensure data quality across the organization. In this post, Subrata Biswas walks through the motivations, features, and architecture behind Airbnb's in-house data quality management framework called "Wall." For more in 
this series, see the Archives. 
Airbnb Tech Blog | Subrata Biswas

title: Applications of survival analysis
summary:
Survival analysis has been a standard tool for decades in clinical research, but data scientists in other domains have mostly ignored it. This introduction to survival analysis highlights practical applications to help jump-start your creative problem solving.
The Crosstab Kite | Brian Kent

title: ML Won't Solve Natural Language Understanding
summary:
In last week's Data Elixir, the posts "What Have Language Models Learned?" and the "Jessica 
Simulation" were super popular. They're great demonstrations but ultimately, they treat language like data and that approach needs to be reconsidered if we're going to make progress towards natural language understanding. Here's why.
The Gradient | Walid S. Saba

title: Share Databases, Not Files
An Introduction to Statistical Learning (ISLR)
summary:
The long-awaited second edition of this popular statistics text has just been released and it's been significantly expanded. Topics cover some of the most important modeling and prediction techniques and is intended to be accessible to a broad audience. Free to download.
Gareth James, Daniela Witten, Trevor Hastie, Robert Tibshirani

title: ISLR tidymodels Labs
summary:
If you're planning to read the 2nd edition of An Introduction to Statistical Learning (above), learn tidymodels too with this collection of labs that have been rewritten from the book to use tidymodels packages. As much as possible, these labs stay true to the original material.
Emil Hvitfeldt

title: 📺 ML YouTube Courses
summary:
Great collection of some of the best and most recent machine learning courses available on YouTube. 
GitHub | dair.ai

title: The local minima of suckiness
summary:
How to become good by getting slowly less bad.
Vicki Boykis

title: Visualizing a codebase
summary:
How could visualization be used to quickly show the structure of a codebase? Would that be useful? Check it out!
Amelia Wattenberger

title: The Typical Weather Anywhere on Earth
summary:
Awesome visualizations for the typical weather at nearly 150K locations around the world. Get graphical reports for temperature, precipitation, cloud cover, wind, sunrise/sunset, and more. 
Weather Spark

title: AI doesn’t have to be too complicated or expensive
summary:
For companies that are interested in using AI but don't have access to vast troves of data, there hasn't been a clear path to follow. But because of that, those industries may be the best untapped opportunities for AI. In this article, Andrew Ng takes a look at the issues, the opportunities, and why now is the time to get started.
Harvard Business Review | Andrew Ng

title: Data Science & Analytics Salary Increases in 2021
summary:
This summary of a new Burtch Works Report shows how salaries have changed over the past year and what to expect going forward. For data science and analytics professionals, the trends look great. Follow the links to download the full 50 page report.
Burtch Works

title: Add Vector-Search to Production Applications
summary: Pinecone makes it easy to add vector similarity search to production applications. No more hassles of tuning algorithms or building and maintaining infrastructure. Try it for semantic text search, image/audio search, recommendation systems, and other applications.

title: What Have Language Models Learned?
summary:
Great interactive post that shows how language models understand the world. Especially, if language models are new for you, this is a must-read post!
Google | PAIR Explorables

title: What's bad about Julia?
summary:
This post is about all the major disadvantages of Julia, written by an knowledgeable Julia user and fan. "Learning why you may not want to choose to use a tool is just as important as learning why you may."
Jakob Nybo Nissen

title: SQL Snippets
summary:
If you have a notebook with miscellaneous bits of SQL code, you'll appreciate this searchable, crowd-sourced collection of SQL snippets. Covers a variety of uses for PostgreSQL, BigQuery, Redshift and more. 
Count

title: Share Databases, Not Files
summary:
Help eliminate the CSV. bit.io is the fastest way to create, share, and collaborate on a real database. Get a Postgres-compatible database in one-click with easy, secure permissions and zero management. Join us in creating a single place for public and private data that makes everyone immediately productive with data. Try it now!
// sponsored

title: QuestDB
summary:
QuestDB is an open-source SQL database that's built for performance and optimized for time-series data. It's currently used in production environments and claims to be the fastest open-source option for time-series. Follow the links for a live demo and there's also a worthwhile discussion on Hacker News about its capabilities.
GitHub | QuestDB

title: Shapash
summary:
Shapash is a Python library that provides a variety of visualizations to help make machine learning models easy to interpret and understand.
GitHub | MAIF

title: Awesome MLOps
summary:
This curated collection of MLOps resources includes books, articles, papers, talks, tooling, newsletters, communities and more. Start with the first section, "MLOps Core."
Larysa Visengeriyeva

title: The Jessica Simulation
summary:
After the death of the woman he loved, Joshua Barbeau turned to a GPT-3 powered website to speak to her once again. These are early days for experiments like this but gven enough journal writings, letters, posts and tweets, could a GPT-3 bot be used to make someone live forever? And if so, would that be a good thing?
San Francisco Chronicle | Jason Fagone

title: What Ever Happened to IBM’s Watson?
summary:
IBM’s artificial intelligence was supposed to transform industries and generate riches for the company. Neither has panned out. Now, IBM has settled on a humbler vision for Watson.
The New York Times | Steve Lohr

title: Understanding Bias in AI: What is it, how to identify it, and how to mitigate it.
summary: It’s no secret...bias in AI is a problem. The more powerful AI capacity becomes, the more important it becomes to ensure that we are producing tools that make life better for more people, not simply scaling and perpetuating forms of error. That’s why we’ve created a guide to understanding and addressing possible sources of bias for your AI/ML project.

title: BirdNET
summary:
BirdNET is a research platform for recognizing bird calls at scale. This is an awesome introduction to the project, including challenges, live demos, and links to free apps. For a look at the machine learning algorithms that drive it, see Machine Learning at Macaulay Library >>
Cornell Lab of Ornithology | Macaulay Library

title: Machine-learning on dirty data in Python: a tutorial
summary:
There are two Python tutorials here for working with dirty data. The first tutorial shows how to predict missing values and the second shows how to work with non normalized strings.
Dirty data science

title: Testing Julia: Fast as Fortran, Beautiful as Python
summary:
This post walks through a series of tests to compare the performance and code simplicity of Julia, Numpy, and Fortran. There's more to do but the verdict so far is super enthusiastic for Julia.
MatecDev | Martin D. Maas, Ph.D

title: What is the right level of specialization?
summary:
The fragmentation of the data science space seems to be never ending. How much of that specialization is a good thing? When is it bad? This is a short, thoughtful post to help you keep your eye on the ball.
Erik Bernhardsson

title: 30 Days of ML
summary:
New to machine learning? Sign up for this new Kaggle challenge to go from beginner to Kaggle competitor in just 30 days. The prerequisites are minimal and it's no cost to join.
Kaggle

title: Add Vector-Search to Production Applications
summary:
Pinecone makes it easy to add vector similarity search to production applications. No more hassles of tuning algorithms or building and maintaining infrastructure. Try it for semantic text search, image/audio search, recommendation systems, and other applications.
// sponsored

title: Handbook of Regression Modeling in People Analytics
summary:
This new book teaches how to do a wide range of statistical analyses in both R and in Python, ranging from simple hypothesis testing to advanced multivariate modeling. Although it's primarily focused on examples related to the analysis of people and talent, the methods easily transfer to other disciplines. Free to read online.
Keith McNulty

title: In defense of simple charts
summary:
Simple visualizations don't need to be boring. Here's why, and how, to create great visualizations using simple charting tools. This is a great post that includes lots of examples.
Datawrapper | Lisa Charlotte Rost

title: 100 Days of D3
summary:
In this collection of D3 tutorials, Sandra Becker introduces a new chart type every few days with example notebooks, references, and video walk-throughs. Follow along for an easy way to learn D3. 
Observable | Sandra Becker

title: Maia, a human-oriented AI for chess
summary:
AI-powered chess engines can consistently beat human players. But what if instead of beating humans, an AI engine was trained to understand humans and match its game to a specific player’s playing style? Could it help humans improve their game? Meet Maia, a chess engine that aims to bridge the gap between AI and human chess play.
Microsoft Research

title: For SQL
summary:
As a counter to last week's popular article "Against SQL," Pedram Navid takes a look at SQL from a different perspective. SQL has become the universal language for data and many people who work with SQL everyday are for SQL. But articles that attack SQL for its technical imperfections reinforce what's become a class divide between "Software Engineers" and "Data People." Wherever you work in data, there are important issues brewing here.
​data based | Pedram Navid

title: Analytics is at a crossroads
summary:
Benn Stancil's response to the For/Against SQL posts explores the emergence of a new role, the "analytics engineer," and the crossroads it presents for analytics. Down one path, analysts are largely measured by technical skills on a continuous spectrum with engineers. Down the other path, being an analyst requires great critical thinking and not necessarily technical skills. This is an insightful post that speaks to the heart of an important debate.
Benn Stancil

title: ADX Webinar: Using ESG data to drive business value
summary: Join AWS Data Exchange and a panel of data experts to learn how companies are using ESG data to move beyond the reporting benchmark, deepen business insights, and create competitive differentiation.

title: Let's get analytical about ML model updates
summary:
Is it time to retrain your machine learning model? Even though data science is all about the data, the answer to this question is oftentimes based on a gut feeling. Here's how to do better.
Evidently AI | Elena Samuylova, Emeli Dral

title: Learning Kedro
summary:
This introductory tutorial explores the open-source Python framework called Kedro. Kedro uses concepts from software engineering to help you create ML code that's reproducible, maintainable and modular.
Jo Stichbury

title: The Quick & Dirty Guide to Building a Data Platform
summary:
There are a lot of technologies you could use to build a data platform - but what do you really need?
Monte Carlo Data | Barr Moses, Lior Gavish

title: Workflows for querying databases via R
summary:
In this post, Emily Riederer walks through a few useful patterns for querying databases in R.
Emily Riederer

title: How to become a better R code detective?
summary:
These tips and resources will help you approach unfamiliar code and get better at debugging and reading it.
Maëlle Salmon

title: Selecting data labeling tools doesn’t have to be hard
summary:
Preparing data for an AI system can be challenging, laborious, and expensive. Luckily there’s a litany of tools that mitigate the tedium of the process. Selecting the right tool, however, is a challenge on its own. iMerit, a provider of high-quality AI training data shares simple tips and insights on making the right choice, based on first-hand experience. Read here.
// sponsored

title: Charting the ‘Data for Good’ Landscape
summary:
"Data for Good" means different things to different people, which makes the space less effective than it might be otherwise. In this post, Jake Porway introduces the Data for Good landscape, including challenges, opportunities and links to key initiatives.
data dot org | Jake Porway

title: Is This Prime?
summary:
This game was recently resurrected on Hacker News and quickly racked up over 100K plays. How many primes can you guess in a minute?
Christian Lawson-Perfect

title: Top 10 ideas in statistics over past 50 years
summary:
Andrew Gelman, a statistics professor at Columbia, and Aki Vehtari, a computer science professor at Finland’s Aalto University, recently published a list of the most important statistical ideas in the last 50 years. Here, they break it down in easy-to-understand terms.
Columbia News | Kim Martineau

title: Roadmap: Data Infrastructure
summary:
A wave of startups is enabling the next generation of data-driven businesses. They offer better and easier-to-use infrastructure for accessing, analyzing, and furthering the use of data. Here's how the team at Bessemer Venture Partners thinks about this space and the key trends that are driving innovation.
Bessemer Venture Partners

title: A/B Test Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them
summary:
A/B tests can measurably improve our product and create a better experience for the majority of our users. But, if we’re not careful, they can keep us chasing product changes that do almost nothing at all. 
Here's what to keep in mind.

title: Against SQL
summary:
SQL was initially developed 50 years ago and in spite of its flaws, it's become the universal language for data. This post explores SQL's many imperfections and what an ideal replacement might look like. There's a lot to consider here and, not surprisingly, the post stirred up a lot of discussion around the web. Also, see the post on Hacker 
News.
Jamie Brandon

title: Self-serve is a feeling
summary:
Self-serve analytics tools can empower business users to answer their own questions but what does "self-serve" mean exactly? And how is it different for different users? Understanding that is key to building tools that are actually useful. Enter, the self-serve Turing Test...
Benn Stancil

title: Causal Inference in the Wild: Elasticity Pricing
summary:
There are a lot of good articles about the theory of causal inference but not many examples of real-world applications. In this tutorial, Lars Roemheld shows how machine learning can improve causal inference in industry using elasticity pricing. This assumes you already have some understanding of causal inference but overall, it's pretty approachable.
Lars Roemheld

title: Parameterizing and automating Jupyter notebooks
summary:
There are commonly used hacks for changing Jupyter notebook parameters but a tool like papermill offers a much cleaner and reproducible approach. This tutorial starts with an introduction to papermill, walks through an example of parameterization, and discusses ways to fully schedule and automate notebook execution using cron.
Matt Wright

title: Democratize data across your organization with semantic layer
summary:
Join this webinar panel for practical advice from data and analytics leaders at Verizon, Snowflake, EverQuote, and Affinity Federal Credit Union on how to build and foster a data literate, self-service analysis culture at scale using a semantic layer. Register here.
// sponsored

title: Tuplex: Blazing Fast Python Data Science
summary:
Tuplex is a data processing framework that runs Python data science pipelines at the speed of compiled code. It works interactively in the Python toplevel, integrates with Jupyter Notebooks, and provides familiar APIs. Follow the links for downloads and recent papers. 
CS at Brown University

title: Risk Assessment of GitHub Copilot
summary:
It's been a couple weeks since GitHub announced their AI-powered auto-code tool called "Copilot." The demos look amazing but there are a lot of questions. This post dives into the issues and takes a hands-on approach to explore Copilots strengths — and where it could get you into trouble.
0xabad1dea

title: Concise and beautiful algorithms written in Julia
summary:
This collection of Julia examples covers a wide variety of algorithms for machine learning, optimization, reinforcement learning, decision-making, and more. These aren't for production use but are clean examples to learn from. All implementations are working and self-contained, with tests.
GitHub | Robert Moss

title: Hard choices: AI in health care
summary:
From assisting medical procedures and diagnostics to analyzing patterns in research data, AI enhances medical science in many ways. But in practical terms, the confluence of AI and medicine is fraught with controversy.
Yale School of Medicine | Jennifer Huizen

title: The Startups Applying AI To Tackle Climate Change
summary:
Lots of ideas here for worthwhile problems to work on. Sections cover things like climate intelligence, carbon accounting, HVAC, agriculture, utilities, renewables and more. Each section includes a summary of the key issues, who's working on them, approaches, and related links.
Forbes | Rob Toews

title: Mitigate Bias, Duplication, and Costly Errors with High-Quality Data
summary: At Alegion, we understand that when you don't have high-quality training data, it can cost companies millions of dollars. That is why we have created a whitepaper on how our team of experts achieves quality training data, and how you can too. Read more about our four prioritized phases, the significance of quality metrics, and how to implement it all.

title: The Untold Story of SQLite
summary:
SQLite is everywhere. It’s in your web browser, it’s in your phone, it’s probably in your car, and it’s definitely in commercial planes. This is a great interview with SQLite's creator, Richard Hipp, where he tells the story of growing a small open source project beyond his wildest dreams.
CoRecursive | Adam Bell with Richard Hipp

title: The data team: a short story
summary:
This is a story about how work is organized on a data team. It's fictionalized and it's not about the tech. Here's the backdrop: you're brought in to grow a tiny data team (~4 people) at a mid-stage startup (~$10M annual revenue). Good luck!
Erik Bernhardsson

title: Managing Supply and Demand Balance Through ML
summary:
DoorDash is a restaurant delivery service that depends on maintaining a healthy balance between contract delivery people and the demand for orders. Here's how they built a machine learning system that effectively monitors each market's supply and demand and uses incentives to proactively correct imbalances. 
Doordash Engineering

title: Alien Dreams: An Emerging Art Scene
summary:
CLIP is the latest tool in the AI-generated art scene and it's amazing. Here's a high-level view of how it works, screenshots of more than 20 recent masterpieces, and lots of rabbit holes to explore. 
ML @ Berkeley | Charlie Snell

title: Join our research panel, make extra income
summary:
Provide feedback on product messaging for industry-leading B2B companies, get paid $15-$50 per survey. Low-key commitment, 10-15 mins per survey. Learn more about Wynter's research panels
// sponsored

title: testbook - unit testing for Jupyter Notebooks
summary:
testbook helps you set up conventional unit tests for Jupyter Notebooks. Unlike other tools, testbook allows unit tests to be run against notebooks in separate test files, which is cleaner and more effective than writing tests within a notebook. It's easy to use and works with common testing libraries, such as unittest, pytest and nose.
testbook

title: Welcome to the Hugging Face 🤗 Course!
summary:
This free course will teach you about natural language processing (NLP) using libraries from the Hugging Face ecosystem — 🤗 Transformers, 🤗 Datasets, 🤗 Tokenizers, and 🤗 Accelerate. It's an all-star lineup of authors and it looks like an awesome way to get started with NLP.
Hugging Face

title: The strategy-analytics revolution
summary:
From marketing and pricing to customer service and manufacturing, advanced analytics is key to many areas of business. But strategy is different. Strategy tends to rely on creative and thoughtful decision-makers to set aspirations and make bold choices. It's time to change that. Here's why.
McKinsey & Company

title: Mitigate Bias, Duplication, and Costly Errors with High-Quality Data
summary: At Alegion, we understand that when you don't have high-quality training data, it can cost companies millions of dollars. That is why we have created a whitepaper on how our team of experts achieves quality training data, and how you can too. Read more about our four prioritized phases, the significance of quality metrics, and how to implement it all.

title: Real Estate pricing with ML and non-traditional data sources
summary:
Nice overview of how machine learning can be used with non-traditional data to predict real estate prices faster and more accurately than traditional methods. Can an algorithm effectively consider a property’s appearance, surrounding environment and human mobility patterns? Yes, it can.
Tryolabs | María Paz

title: On the “usefulness” of the Netflix Prize
summary:
Ten years ago, Netflix offered a million dollar prize to the team that could most substantially improve the accuracy of the Netflix recommendation algorithm. At the time, turning algorithm development into a public contest was an innovative idea but after it was over, the winning solution was famously never put into production. Here's what happened and how, ultimately, the contest was a huge success.
Xavier Amatriain (former Research/Engineering Director at Netflix)

title: What, Exactly, Does a Data Product Manager Do?
summary:
Data product management is growing fast but what does a data product manager do, exactly? Ask five people and you might get five different answers. Here's a good starting point for understanding this burgeoning field.
Eric Weber

title: Ace your next data science interview
summary:
Get better at data science interviews and sharpen your skills by solving a few questions per week. Join thousands of other data scientists and analysts practicing for interviews! Subscribe to our newsletter.
// sponsored

title: Sports Analytics Reading List
summary:
Regardless of your skill level, this is a great reading list for all things sports analytics. Covers ⚽ 🏀 ⚾ 🏒 ⛳ 🏈 🥊 and more! 
Tech & Data & Sports | Brendan Kent

title: 📚 Introduction to Modern Statistics
summary:
This new text highlights multivariable relationships and simulation-based inference with a heavy emphasis on exploratory data analysis. It's easy to follow and with the interactive tutorials and supplemental downloads, it looks like it would be great as either a self-study guide or for classroom use. Free to access online or download as a PDF.
Mine Çetinkaya-Rundel and Jo Hardin

title: Designing for the Data Visualization Lifecycle
summary:
Many of the tools that are currently used to create visualizations were designed in a different era. Today, the technology to build tools is more capable and, especially in data-driven organizations, visualization is everywhere and data literacy is higher. In this post, Elijah Meeks explores how the landscape has evolved and what's needed now.
Elijah Meeks, Co-Founder and CVO of Noteable

title: Experts doubt ethical AI will be broadly adopted anytime soon
summary:
This new report shows that a majority of tech innovators, business & policy leaders, and researchers & activists believe that the evolution of AI will continue to be focused on optimizing profits and social control. That's easy to understand, especially considering the range of responses here. Even so, many are optimistic about how AI will ultimately be beneficial. This is a thought-provoking longread.
Pew Research Center

title: Using external data in a post-vaccinated world
summary: Join this webinar to discover how AWS Data Exchange provides the data to help you understand consumer behavior for better data insights and business decisions in a post-pandemic economy.

title: What is a "data scientist" or "machine learning engineer", really?
summary:
Job titles tend to be overloaded and aren't super helpful for understanding the work that someone does. What does a "Data Scientist" actually do? How about a "Data Analyst?" Or an "ML Engineer?" In this project, Paige Bailey uses survey results from Kaggle, Anaconda and Stack Overflow to explore who does what, and how. Based on the responses, she found 6 distinct clusters; and no apparent correlation to job 
title.
GitHub | Paige Bailey

title: Understanding p-values Through Simulations
summary:
P-values are often misinterpreted or misused. This is a fantastic interactive tool for learning about and/or explaining how p-values work.
Kristoffer Magnusson

title: Applied NLP Thinking: How to Translate Problems into Solutions
summary:
Applied NLP is different than research NLP. With Applied NLP, you'll never ship anything valuable if you abstract out the application goals and treat the work as an optimization problem. This post is a non-technical introduction to thinking through real-world NLP problems and how to approach them. 
Explosion | Ines Montani

title: Using Geospatial Data in R
summary:
Great tutorial for working with geospatial data using R. Starts with an overview of how geospatial data corresponds to places in the real world and then introduces a workflow that includes data management, data wrangling with simple features, and ways to visualize geospatial data. This is well-organized and includes lots of code snippets, linked references, and screenshots along the way.
Method Bites

title: StreamSets: Build Smart Data Pipelines for Free
summary:
Get early access to the new StreamSets DataOps Platform. Quickly build and deploy streaming, batch, CDC, ETL and ML pipelines across hybrid and multi-cloud. Plus, handle data drift automatically so jobs keep running even when schemas and structures change. Get early access now.
// sponsored

title: Kats - One stop shop for time series analysis in Python
summary:
Kats is a lightweight, easy to use, and extendable framework that aims to be a one-stop shop for time series analysis, including detection, forecasting, feature extraction/embedding, multivariate analysis, etc. Kats is from Facebook's Infrastructure Data Science team and is open-sourced with an MIT license.
Facebook Research

title: Exploring Data Lineage with OpenLineage
summary:
OpenLineage is an open platform for collecting and analyzing data lineage. It tracks metadata about datasets, jobs, and runs, and gives users the information they need to identify the root cause of complex issues. Here's how to get started.
Hightouch | Pedram Navid

title: Machine Learning Interviews Book
summary:
Regardless of what side of the table you're on, this is an awesome new resource for anyone who's interviewing for machine learning roles. Along with a wide range of sample questions, this includes discussion of typical roles, types of companies, interview processes, how to think through an offer, do's and don'ts, useful resources and much more. This is an open-source book that's being actively developed.
Chip Huyen

title: When Graphs Are a Matter of Life and Death
summary:
Charts may seem ordinary and mundane until you stop to think about the gigantic conceptual leap it took to first imagine them. And then you can't help but be blown away by the stunning ingenuity of humanity.
The New Yorker | Hannah Fry

title: Don't Feed the Thought Leaders
summary:
This is a fictionalized story about software but it's easy to see how it applies more generally. Feeding a know-it-all tends to create: 1) hype cycles & technical debt, and 2) exciting conference talks 🤪🚀
Earthly | Adam Gordon Bell

title: Ray Summit: Scalable ML & AI for everyone
summary:
Want to learn the best way to scale? Ray Summit brings together data scientists and engineers to build scalable ML & AI using Ray, the dominant platform for distributed computing. Learn about top trends in machine learning & AI, ML in production, reinforcement 
learning, cloud computing & more. Register to join live or on-demand.

title: What the Heck is a Data Mesh?!
summary:
Great introduction to data meshes, starting with the idea of "data as a product." Everything flows from there —  the need for decentralization, self-serve infrastructure, federated governance, etc. 
Chris Riccomini

title: The Rise of the Metadata Lake
summary:
Most organizations have only just scratched the surface of what's possible with metadata. But as metadata continues to grow in volume, it's becoming increasingly important to think about how it can be used and stored more effectively. Introducing, the metadata lake...
humans of data

title: Patterns for Personalizing Recommendations & Search
summary:
Personalization is the process of customizing each user's experience. In his latest post, Eugene Yan explores common personalization approaches for search and recommendations and shows how they work. Covers bandits, embedding+MLP, sequences, graph, and user embeddings.
Eugene Yan

title: Increasing Experimentation Accuracy and Speed
summary:
Etsy's Online Experimentation Science team is a mix of statisticians and engineers that's focused on what's essentially sophisticated A/B testing. This post is a deep dive into how they use a statistical method called CUPED to quickly learn which features improve the user experience.
Etsy | Code as Craft

title: Linear Algebra for Machine Learning
summary:
Tai-Danae Bradley has a gift for clear explanations and teaching. In this session of Machine Learning Tech Talks, she offers a friendly introduction to linear algebra that isn't a technical deep dive but is super clear if you're just getting started.
YouTube | Tai-Danae Bradley, PhD

title: Democratize data & scale augmented analytics
summary:
Join this webinar panel for practical advice on how to evolve your business intelligence with augmented analytics and scale data science initiatives. You’ll learn from top industry strategists and technologists from DataRobot, DataPrime, and more, on how to integrate AI and BI, and how to augment analytics to scale predictive and prescriptive analytics as well as machine learning. Save your spot.
// sponsored

title: Leafmap
summary:
Leafmap is a Python package for geospatial analysis and interactive mapping with Jupyter. It's built on widely used geospatial and data science packages, such as folium and ipyleaflet (for creating interactive maps), WhiteboxTools and whiteboxgui (for analyzing geospatial data), and ipywidgets (for designing interactive interfaces).
GitHub | Qiusheng Wu

title: Reproducible Data Science
summary:
This online text offers a hands-on introduction to open, reproducible, and ethical data analysis. Covers reproducible workflows, data wrangling, exploratory analysis, data visualization, pattern discovery, prediction & machine learning, causal inference, and network analysis.
Valentin Danchev

title: Machine learning is booming in medicine. It’s also facing a credibility crisis.
summary:
Experts say fatal flaws in the methodology of many machine learning papers make it hard to have faith in published claims.
STAT | Casey Ross

title: Online Data Science Programs from Drexel University
summary: Find your algorithm for success with an online data science degree from Drexel University. Gain essential skills in tool creation and development, data and text mining, trend identification, and data manipulation and summarization by using leading industry technology to apply to your career. Learn more.

title: How Airbnb Achieved Metric Consistency at Scale - Part 2
summary:
This second post in a series walks through the core design principles of Airbnb's in-house metric platform called "Minerva." Specifically, here's how Airbnb defines, versions, and back-fills datasets to effectively manage its data at scale. This a useful post that includes lots of details and rationale for why things work they way they do.
Airbnb Engineering & Data Science | Amit Pahwa et al.

title: Building Effective Data Science Teams
summary:
Whether you're the first data person at your organization or leading a team of hundreds, creating an effective data team depends on a lot more than the tech you're using. In this transcript of a recent panel discussion, data science leaders from a variety of organizations share their insights.
RStudio Blog | Rachael Dempsey

title: Saturn Cloud: End-to-End Data Science & Machine Learning Platform
summary:
Join thousands of data scientists creating faster and more scalable Python projects with Hosted Dask, GPUs, and more. Switch from working on a laptop to a cloud instance with hosted Jupyter, use jobs and deployments to run repeating tasks, host APIs, and deploy dashboards. Join for free here
// sponsored

title: JupyterLite - browser-based interactive computing
summary:
JupyterLite is a WebAssembly (Wasm) powered Jupyter distribution that runs entirely in the browser. This is an early release, built from the ground-up using JupyterLab components and extensions. Real-time collaboration is said to be Coming Soon! Follow the links for a live demo.
GitHub | Jeremy Tuloup

title: Stemma: Helping you trust your data
summary:
Amundsen is the leading open-source data catalog. It has the largest and fastest-growing community and the most integrations. Stemma brings you Amundsen and more, with enterprise management and richer metadata.
Mark Grover

title: Data Science at the Command Line, 2nd edition
summary:
This hands-on guide shows how command line tools can help you be more be efficient and productive with data. The new second edition will be published in October and is available to read online while it's being finalized. Read the first edition here >>
Jeroen Janssens

title: R for Public Health
summary:
Nice collection of resources for people who are interested in working with R in a public health context. Includes courses, books, and key packages to know.
R Views | Joseph Rickert

title: Visualizing Distributions with Raincloud Plots
summary:
Great tutorial that shows how boxplots can be problematic, how to improve them, and alternative techniques that can be used to show summary statistics, as well as the true distribution of the raw data. Includes lots of examples and sample code using ggplot2.
Cédric Scherer

title: Scientific visualizations in the browser for Python
summary:
They can be super effective but if you're not a web expert, building dynamic visualizations for the web can be daunting. In this guide, Patrick Mineault presents a variety of web visualization frameworks, starting with the lowest barrier to entry as possible. It's written from the perspective of a Python user but for the most part, Python isn't required. 
Patrick Mineault

title: Nasty, brutish and short: The life of the modern CDO
summary:
What does a Chief Data Officer do exactly? This short post offers a glimpse into the world of a CDO and how they're often not set up for success within their organizations.
LinkedIn | Ian Thomas

title: To regulate AI, try playing in a sandbox
summary:
In the EU's recently proposed AI regulations, the word "sandbox" is mentioned 38 times. The idea is to develop and test AI applications in low-stakes, monitored environments before rolling them out to the general public. Experts agree that it's a step in the right direction but it's no silver bullet.
Emerging Tech Brew | Dan McCarthy

title: Mitigate Bias, Duplication, and Costly Errors with High-Quality Data
summary: At Alegion, we understand that when you don't have high-quality training data, it can cost companies millions of dollars. That is why we have created a whitepaper on how our team of experts achieves quality training data, and how you can too. Read more about our four prioritized phases, the significance of quality metrics, and how to implement it all.

title: Understanding the data (error) generating processes for data validation
summary:
In stats, we talk about the data generating process (DGP), yet data validation is often conducted without a theory of error generation. This post explores some failure models in ELT and implications for data consumers on effective validation.
Emily Riederer

title: JavaScript for Data Analysis
summary:
JavaScript may not be widely considered as important for working with data but the tools are evolving and JavaScript already excels at enabling collaboration and communication on the web. In this post, Mike Bostock, creator of D3.js and the Observable platform, makes a case for JavaScript as a key language for data and what to expect in the coming years.
Mike Bostock

title: Interactive Gaussian Process Visualization
summary:
This interactive visualization of Gaussian processes helps make it easy to understand prior and posterior kernel functions. The description regarding Gaussian processes is high-level but follow the link in the "Background" section for an in-depth tutorial.
Infinite Curiosity

title: Can you build an ML model to monitor another model?
summary:
Can you train a machine learning model to predict your model's mistakes? It sounds reasonable on the surface. Machine learning models make mistakes. Let's take these mistakes and train another model to predict the missteps of the first one! Sort of a "trust detector," based on learnings from how our model did in the past.
Evidently AI | Emeli Dral and Elena Samuylova

title: Session-based Recommender Systems
summary:
Session-based recommendation algorithms provide recommendations based solely on a user's interactions in a single session. That's useful because it doesn't require a history of that user's preferences. This introduction shows how these algorithms work, how to evaluate them, and things to consider if you're building your own.
Cloudera Fast Forward

title: Apply today: Master of Data Science for Public Policy
summary:
Passionate about turning data into valuable insights for the common good? Join the next cohort of the Master of Data Science for Public Policy (MDS) at the Hertie School in Berlin, Germany. This two-year programme taught entirely in English welcomes students from any academic discipline who are interested in using data to solve real-world challenges. Are you curious about the MDS? Get in touch.
// sponsored

title: AgentPy - Agent-based modeling in Python
summary:
AgentPy is an open-source library for the development and analysis of agent-based models in Python. The framework integrates the tasks of model design, interactive simulations, numerical experiments, and data analysis within a single environment, and is optimized for interactive computing with IPython and Jupyter.
agentpy | Joël Foramitti

title: NocoDB - The Open Source Airtable Alternative
summary:
NocoDB is an open-source Airtable alternative that turns your relational databases into "smart-spreadsheets." It connects to cloud services like S3 for storage and things like Slack, Twilio, Discord, etc via an App Store for workflow automations. This project was open-sourced just last week and already has over 10K stars! Also, see the Hacker News discussion >>
GitHub | nocodb

title: Analytics Engineering Everywhere
summary:
"While everyone was focused on the rise of data science, another discipline has been quietly taking shape, driven not by glitzy articles in Harvard Business Review, but by the people working in the trenches in data-intensive roles. They call it the analytics engineer..."
Jason Ganz

title: Be Careful When Interpreting Predictive Models in Search of Causal Insights
summary:
A careful exploration of the pitfalls of trying to extract causal insights from modern predictive machine learning models.
Scott Lundberg et al. from Microsoft

title: A guide to marketplace survival and growth
summary: Learn how data leaders at Lyft, Domain, and Patreon navigated market change with real-time data, growth indicators, and data heroes.

title: Automated Data Wrangling
summary:
A growing array of techniques apply machine learning directly to the problems of data wrangling. They often start out as open research projects but then become proprietary. How can we build automated data wrangling systems for open data? This is a nice rabbit hole with lots of linked references to explore.
Catalyst Cooperative | Zane Selvans

title: Analytics is a mess
summary:
"Data isn’t objective, and analysis isn’t structured. It’s just as creative, and just as messy, as the papers I ran away from in college..." Great essay!
Benn Stancil

title: Lessons on ML Platforms — from Netflix, DoorDash, Spotify, and more
summary:
Through scouring conference talks and blog posts from the past several years, this post explores the common components and capabilities of machine learning platforms at eleven large tech companies.
Ernest Chan

title: Einstellung Effect: How What You Know Can Hurt You
summary:
The Einstellung effect is a psychological phenomenon that changes the way we come to solutions. Here's how it specifically applies to data science and how to keep it from hindering innovation.
Exaptive Blog | Stephen Arra

title: Finding the next big thing just got easy
Flat Data
summary:
Flat Data is a new collection of tools from GitHub that make it easy to automatically fetch and work with live-updating data in your repos. With Flat Actions, you can get data from either HTTP endpoints or SQL queries, transform that data via scripts, view changes in the data over time, and easily build workflows to suit your needs. This looks awesome!
GitHub Office of the CTO

title: Dot Plots
summary:
Dot Plots are more than just histograms and they're a lot more interesting and useful than they may seem at first glance. This is a nice introduction to how they work, including interactive examples.
UW Interactive Data Lab | Jeffrey Heer

title: Be Decision-Driven Not Data-Driven
summary:
Since launching its annual executive survey in 2012, NewVantage Partners has watched leading companies steadily invest in efforts to become more data-driven. Nearly 99% of reporting companies report active investments in data initiatives and yet, only 24% claim to be in a data-driven organization. Maybe being data-driven is the wrong goal...
Techno Sapien | Mark Palmer

title: Ray Summit: Scalable ML & AI for everyone
summary: Want to learn the best way to scale? Ray Summit brings together data scientists and engineers to build scalable ML & AI using Ray, the dominant platform for distributed computing. Learn about top trends in machine learning & AI, ML in production, reinforcement learning, cloud computing & more. Register to join live or on-demand.

title: Why Dagster is the next-generation data orchestrator
summary:
Dagster is a data orchestrator for machine learning, analytics, and ETL. It's similar to Airflow but it handles each stage of the data life cycle differently. In this post, Nick Schrock compares the two systems and explores the advantages of using Dagster.
Dagster Blog | Nick Schrock

title: Using PostgreSQL as a Data Warehouse
summary:
With some tweaking, Postgres can be a great data warehouse. Here's why that's worth considering and how to configure it.
Narrator | Cedric Dussud

title: Good Data Scientist, Bad Data Scientist
summary:
Regardless of what part of the stack you work on, there are common traits that separate "good" data scientists from "bad" data scientists. This short post applies to most people in tech and is  good food for thought.
Ian Whitestone

title: What is a Vector Database?
summary:
Vector embeddings are fundamental parts of many recommendation and search algorithms and they've become increasingly important to machine learning applications. This post introduces vector embeddings, their unique needs and how, ultimately, a new type of database is needed.
Pinecone Blog | Rajat Tripathi

title: Scale Transform: The Present and Future of AI
summary:
Scale Transform broke records and brought together more than 10,000+ leading researchers, practitioners, and executives. The conference featured an all-star line-up of 27 of the leading AI researchers and practitioners and 19 sessions from the latest research breakthroughs to the real-world impact across industries.
// sponsored

title: Greykite for flexible, intuitive, and fast forecasting
summary:
Greykite is an open-source Python library that was developed to support LinkedIn’s forecasting needs. Its main forecasting algorithm, called Silverkite, is fast, accurate, and intuitive, making it suitable for interactive and automated forecasting at scale.
Linkedin Engineering Blog | Reza Hosseini

title: Data Profiler | What's in your data?
summary:
The DataProfiler is a Python library that makes it easy to extract schema, statistics and entities from your datasets. Data Profiles can then be used in downstream applications or reports.
GitHub | Capital One

title: Data Week
summary:
General Assembly's Data Week is happening THIS WEEK! Sessions are scheduled throughout the week and cover things like bias detection, communicating with data, career development, playlist recommenders, and lots more. All sessions are online and free. 
General Assembly

title: Introducing Dataflow, a self-hosted Observable Notebook Editor
summary:
Dataflow is a standalone notebook editor for Observable. Create, run, and compile Observable notebooks on your own machine! MIT license.
Oberservable | Alex Garcia

title: Falx: Visualization by Example
summary:
Falx is a visualization-by-example tool that uses small examples of a dataset to show how the full dataset should be visualized. This post is a nice introduction to the project. Follow the links for an online demo.
UCBerkeley RISELab

title: New AI laws are coming. Is your organization ready?
summary:
Over the past few weeks, lawmakers and regulators around the world have been discussing new restrictions on how companies use AI. Three trends are emerging. Here's what it's all about and how companies can take action now to prepare.​
Harvard Business Review | Andrew Burt

title: Mitigate Bias, Duplication, and Costly Errors with High-Quality Data
summary: At Alegion, we understand that when you don't have high-quality training data, it can cost companies millions of dollars. That is why we have created a whitepaper on how our team of experts achieves quality training data, and how you can too. Read more about our four prioritized phases, the significance of quality metrics, and how to implement it all.

title: Machine Learning, Ethics, and Open Source Licensing
summary:
In this second of a two-part series, Christopher Moran explores how new approaches to open source licensing could affect the impact that ML systems have in the world. Domain-specific licenses, for instance, are particularly well-suited for ML and would enable developers to create clear and enforceable boundaries for how their work is used.
The Gradient | Christopher Moran

title: A Tale of Six  States
summary:
Even when the data is similar, states across the U.S. have very different approaches for making it available. Some states offer downloadable csv files, others display data in static web tables, a couple states allow access via Java Serverlets, and on, and on. In this post, ​Emily Riederer uses 2020 election data as a vehicle to explore different tools for data extraction. 
Emily Riederer

title: Segmenting the Data Analytics Stack
summary:
In this recorded discussion from Clubhouse, a16z general partner Martin Casado digs into the data analytics stack, the future of SQL, and the use cases for streaming data with leaders from Starburst, Superset and Imply.
a16z Live

title: DAGsHub: Scale Data Science Teamwork
summary:
Automate mundane tasks on top of an open stack. Quickly start with best-in-class tools - DVC, Git & MLflow. Track experiments, push data, sync, and integrate the tools you love. Join a hands-on community of data scientists. Get started for free with DAGsHub
// sponsored

title: 📊 Thinking in Data
summary:
Thinking in Data is a curated set of Visual Studio Code extensions for data analysis, visualization, and collaboration. It's inspired by, and includes, the Thinking in Code extension pack. If you're familiar with RStudio, MATLAB, Spyder, JupyterLab, or other scientific IDEs, but have felt overwhelmed by the VS Code extension marketplace, this is a great place to start.
GitHub | Paige Bailey

title: Opyrator
summary:
Opyrator enables you to quickly turn your python functions into microservices with auto-generated web APIs, interactive GUIs, and more. This is an early release but there's a LOT of interest already.
GitHub | Machine Learning Tooling

title: Spreadsheet Munging Strategies
summary:
It's not new but this online book is a treasure trove of R recipes that will help you get data out of spreadsheets, "no matter how peculiar."  
Duncan Garmonsway

title: Clustergam: visualisation of cluster analysis
summary:
When using cluster analysis to identify groups in your data, it's common to use an algorithm like K-Means, which requires the specification of a number of clusters. In this post, Martin Fleischmann introduces a Python package that shows the behavior of common cluster algorithms, which can be used to determine the optimal number of clusters.  
Martin Fleischmann

title: Why AI That Teaches Itself is the Next Big Thing
summary:
Most ML systems leverage historical data to make predictions. But learning through trial and error leads to more creative solutions.
Harvard Business Review

title: How third-party data enhances location accuracy
summary: Join AWS Data Exchange for a discussion on how Yum! Brands and other organizations are leveraging location-based data to boost in-app location accuracy, increase in-store foot traffic, and expand ecommerce business.

title: Practical SQL for Data Analysis
summary:
In this epic post, Haki Benita shows how to use SQL to perform fast and efficient data analysis. Pivot tables, subtotals, linear regression, binning, and interpolation can all be done with SQL and in many cases, that's the best approach. There's a lot of detail here and a linked index makes it easy to jump around. For more, see the discussion on Hacker News >>
Haki Benita

title: Search: Query Matching via Lexical, Graph, and Embedding Methods
summary:
Search and recommendations have a lot in common but search also has a user’s query as an input. In his latest post, Eugene Yan explores the three main methods that are used in industry to match those queries to documents, people and products. Includes examples from Amazon, Google, Uber, Yahoo, Facebook and more.  
 Eugene Yan

title: How Airbnb Achieved Metric Consistency at Scale
summary:
This is the first of a new series that explores Airbnb's in-house metric platform called "Minerva." Minerva is used across the company as the single source of truth for analytics, reporting, and experimentation. This post walks through the problems being solved, Minerva's core features and the ecosystem of tools it has enabled.  
Airbnb Engineering & Data Science | Robert Chang

title: From Sequential to Parallel, a story about Bayesian Hyperparameter Optimization
summary:
Here's how Riskified dramatically reduced the run time of a Bayesian hyperparameter search process by making each step more inefficient.
Riskified Technology | Andres Asaravicius

title: Enroll in a Metis Short Immersive Course!
summary:
These expert-led short immersive courses will help you upskill in specific data science & analytics topics in 2-4 weeks. Enroll today and gain in-demand data skills while completing a portfolio-ready project.
// sponsored

title: Soda SQL
summary:
Soda SQL is an open-source command-line tool that makes it easy to run tests on SQL-accessible data to find invalid, missing, or unexpected data. When tests fail, they surface "bad" data that you can fix to ensure that downstream analysts are using "good" data to make decisions.
GitHub | Soda Data Monitoring

title: DrawData
summary:
This small python package lets you draw a dataset in a Jupyter Notebook. Use it for teaching, playing with ideas or to help understand how machine learning models might make predictions.
GitHub | Vincent D. Warmerdam

title: Tidyverse Skills for Data Science
summary:
Great introduction to the Tidyverse and how to use its collection of packages for doing data science. This online book covers a wide variety of topics in data wrangling, visualization and modeling. 
JHU Data Science Lab

title: Reactive, reproducible, collaborative: computational notebooks evolve
summary:
The notebook ecosystem has evolved a lot since IPython's introduction ten years ago. Here's how a new breed of notebooks is taking data visualization and collaborative functionality to the next level. 
Nature

title: Cetacean Translation Initiative
summary:
Machine learning has enabled groundbreaking advances in human language translation so it's not surprising that research is also underway to enable inter-species communication. It's early days still but the research is fascinating. This paper introduces a road map and rationale for a new research effort that intends to decode Sperm Whale vocalizations! For more, see the related article with recordings and photos at National Geographic >> 
arXiv

title: Enroll in a Metis Short Immersive Course!
summary:
These expert-led short immersive courses will help you upskill in specific data science & analytics topics in 2-4 weeks. Enroll today
and gain in-demand data skills while completing a portfolio-ready project.

title: Scaling Data: data informed to data driven to data led
summary:
Successful companies approach data as a lever for growth, not as a team to hire or a set of tools. In other words, success comes from being data led, not data informed. It's more than just how you think about it. Getting to data led requires a data maturity shift and you need to evolve key capabilities along the way. This roadmap shows how.
Reforge | Crystal Widjaja

title: Run Your Data Team Like A Product Team
summary:
If you're still not convinced about the limitations of being in a data-informed organization, this post takes a different approach and shows how many data teams get stuck in a service-oriented culture where the task is to answer other people's questions. Here's how that squanders the data team's real potential and what you should do instead.
Locally Optimistic | Emilie Schario and Taylor A. Murphy, PhD

title: A Coherent Model for the Kentucky Derby
summary:
In his latest post, Peter Cotton shows how to construct a coherent model for the upcoming Kentucky Derby. The post is based on a recent paper where he introduces a scalable approach for inferring the distributions of participant scores in a multi-party contest. Beyond the track, it's useful for things like e-commerce, auto ML, bandit-like problems, and more.
Microprediction | Peter Cotton

title: The missing piece of the modern data stack
summary:
Today's data stack is pretty good but is it missing a layer? Benn Stancil makes a convincing point here that a new layer for metrics would go a long way to ensure consistency for some of the most important and common use-cases for data.
Benn Stancil

title: We were promised Strong AI, but instead we got metadata analysis.
summary:
The late nineties dream of search engines was that they would use grand-scale AI to find everything, understand most of it and help us retrieve the best of it. Not much of that has really come true.
Cal Paterson

title: From spreadsheet to interactive web app in 2 minutes
summary:
Eliminate the struggle around structured data. After 6 years of leading data teams @Google, we built Polymer Search, the world's fastest, easiest and in-depth data productivity application to make you excel, regardless of skill level. Experience 100% data automation that boosts expertise and clarity for anyone in 2 mins. Get Early Access for free.
// sponsored

title: Introduction to Computational Thinking
summary:
This current course from MIT uses the Julia language to approach real-world problems with data analysis and computational and mathematical modeling. Lectures, interactive notebooks, and cheatsheets are all freely available. To see if it's for you, check out the short Introduction Video.
MIT

title: The Art of Mathematics in Chalk
summary:
Even when it may be hard to understand, math is beautiful. Photographer Jessica Wynne set out to capture this appeal when she began photographing mathematicians' chalkboards around the world. Some of the photographs are reproduced here and have been collected in a new book: Do Not Erase: Mathematicians and Their Chalkboards.
Scientific American | Clara Moskowitz

title: What’s wrong with MLOps?
summary:
Great essay with insights that apply well beyond MLOps.
Laszlo Sragner

title: Don’t hire top talent; hire for weaknesses.
summary:
Next time you're looking for a new team member, don't try to find the best talent. Hire people that will strengthen your teams’ weaknesses instead. Here's why that's important.
Benji Weber

title: A/B Test Pitfalls and How to Avoid Them | Mode
summary:
A/B tests can measurably improve our product and create a better experience for the majority of our users. But, if we’re not careful, they can keep us chasing product changes that do almost nothing at all. 
Read more here.

title: Time series forecasting: Selecting algorithms
summary:
In this second article in a series, Yasmin Bokobza explores Microsoft's approach to evaluating the accuracy of forecasting models and how his team enables stakeholders to move quickly on their time series problems and make high-quality forecasts.
Data Science at Microsoft | Yasmin Bokobza

title: What is DataOps?
summary:
The term "DataOps" is increasingly being used to describe the collection of tools and processes that are used to automate and monitor everything that supports an organization’s data products and services. This is a great introduction to this emerging discipline, including a framework for a DataOps stack and associated tools and services.
Gradient Flow | Assaf Araki and Ben Lorica

title: What Is Your Model Hiding? A Tutorial on Evaluating ML Models
summary:
There's more to performance than accuracy. Here's how to evaluate the behavior of a classification model before you put it into production.
Evidently AI | Emeli Dral and Elena Samuylova

title: Scaling Self-Service Analytics for Smarter Decisions
summary:
AtScale invites you to join a new webinar panel with speakers from the data & analytics community. This is a free, online event where analytics leaders from General Mills, Affinity Federal Credit Union, EverQuote, and more, will share their experiences building self-service data cultures at scale for their organizations. Register for free.
// sponsored

title: Announcing Feast
summary:
