Feast is an open source feature store for machine learning that intends to be the fastest path to productionizing analytic data for model training and online inference. This 0.1 announcement explores what it can do now and what to look forward to.
Feast Blog

title: nbterm
summary:
nbterm is a new, evolving project  that lets you view, edit and execute Jupyter Notebooks in a terminal. Along with a Command mode, there's an Edit mode lets you navigate and type directly into cells.
GitHub | David Brochart

title: Scikit-learn Course
summary:
This free course is an in-depth introduction to predictive modeling with scikit-learn. The course covers the software tools that are used to build and evaluate predictive pipelines, as well as the related concepts and statistical intuitions.
scikit-learn @ La Fondation Inria

title: Machine Learning for Art
summary:
"ml4a" is a collection of tools and educational resources which apply techniques from machine learning to arts and creativity. The recent update includes a new python library and a new set of models and tutorials to play with.
ml4a

title: R Charts
summary:
This is an awesome new resource for R users. Includes examples of over 1100 charts with reproducible code that's organized in 8 categories and over 50 chart types. Examples cover ggplot2, base R graphics and more.
R Coder

title: Introducing the MAD (ML, AI, Data) Public Co. Index!
summary:
It's rare for articles about investing to make it into Data Elixir but this post by Matt Turck is a nice starting point for data people to invest in what they know. The "MAD Index" is a small basket of publicly traded companies that are as close as possible to being “pure” data or ML/AI. The post covers selection criteria, earnings and key growth metrics.
Matt Turck, VC at FirstMark

title: The Mathematics of how Connections Become Global
summary:
At what point does a meme go viral, a product start to dominate a market or a disease become a pandemic? Here's how a mathematical concept called "percolation theory" can be used to explore network behavior and the effects of randomly adding and/or removing nodes.
Scientific American | Kelsey Houston-Edwards

title:
apply(): the ML Data Engineering Conference
April 21-22
summary: apply() is the first community conference for ML data engineering. This is a free, online event where users and thought leaders will share their experiences. Speakers include thought leaders from Google, Microsoft, LinkedIn, Netflix, DoorDash, Spotify, Pinterest, Stitch Fix, and more. We’d love to have you join us! Register for free.

title: Moving beyond “algorithmic bias is a data problem”
summary:
A lot of people think that bias is a data problem but algorithms are not impartial and some design choices are better than others. Recognizing how model design impacts bias opens up new mitigation techniques that are far less burdensome than comprehensive data collection.
Patterns | Sara Hooker

title: Process large datasets w/o running out of memory
summary:
Great series of articles that show how to process larger-than-RAM datasets in Python. Covers techniques for code structure, data management, Pandas, NumPy, database querying, and more.
PythonSpeed | Itamar Turner-Trauring

title: 10 Things to Know About BERT and the Transformer Architecture That Are Reshaping the AI Landscape
summary:
This post is an awesome overview of some of the most important things that are happening in the fast-paced world of NLP. It's organized in ten sections that show where each technology came from, how it was developed, how it works, and what to expect from it in the near future. The post is fairly high-level with links to key papers to go deeper.
Neptune Blog | Cathal Horan

title: Monte Carlo’s Ultimate Data Observability Checklist
summary:
Building or buying a data observability platform to tackle data quality at your company? Great! But how do you get started? Here are the 26 things you need to know.
// sponsored

title: Data Connector
summary:
Data Connector is a Google Sheets Add-on that lets you import and export data to/from Google Sheets. There are other add-ons that do that too but the focus here is privacy and the code is open-sourced so it can be reviewed. Eventually, it will also support APIs, databases & more.
GitHub | Brent Adamson

title: MC2: A Platform for Secure Analytics and ML
summary:
MC2 is a platform for running secure analytics and machine learning on encrypted data. MC2 enables secure collaboration and lets users outsource their confidential data workloads to the cloud, while ensuring that the data is never exposed unencrypted to the cloud provider.
GitHub |  RISELab, UC Berkeley

title: Exploring Other {ggplot2} Geoms
summary:
ggplot2 has built-in geoms (geometric objects) for common visualizations such as barcharts, histograms, and scatterplots but what if you need something different? This post explores some popular geoms that have been created within the R community, such as streamgraphs, ridgeline plots, sankey diagrams, bump charts, waffle charts and more. Includes screenshots and code snippets for each.
Isabella Velásquez

title: Data scientists are predicting sports injuries with an algorithm
summary:
These days, it's not uncommon for elite athletes to be outfitted with a variety of sensors that track things like heart rate, distance traveled, speed, and more. Coaches are using machine learning to help make sense of all that data and to optimize an athlete's training regimen. This article takes a look at what's possible now and where things are going.
Nature | Andrada Fiscutean

title: Let’s Invent the Future Together
summary: Don’t miss the opportunity to learn the possibilities of scalable #AI infrastructures! Join @Bohr Tasi, @Tina Duong from AMAX @NVIDIAGTC to push operational limits and harness power of accelerated AI computing solutions with outstanding density, superior bandwidth, and lower data center costs. Register free and learn more in AMAX’s interactive sessions during GTC21: https://nvda.ws/3q0wMAX

title: Everyone wants to do model work, not the data work
summary:
If you haven't seen it yet, this is a great paper that's based on interviews with more than 50 AI practitioners around the world. The authors explore data practices in high stakes domains and find that "data is the most under-valued and de-glamorized aspect of AI." Clients want "magic" but when the quality of the underlying data is neglected, cascading problems ensue. It's not surprising but this is a good exploration of the issues.
Google Research

title: You’re probably measuring your treatment effect incorrectly
summary:
Imagine you've developed a new health program and you want to measure how much the treatment affected the people who participated. That may sound easy but look closer and you'll see that it's more complicated than you might think...
Chris Said

title: Predicting FT Trending Topics
summary:
At the Financial Times, Trending Topics Prediction is a data science model that surfaces trends that are hard to spot to its journalists. This post walks through its design, including details about the data, the model, time-series analysis, back-testing, and deployment.
Financial Times Product & Technology

title: Data Monitoring at Scale with SQL and ML
summary:
At a high level, machine learning is key for data observability at scale. In this final part of a series, Barr Moses and Ryan Kearns explain why and show how data teams can create their own production-quality data observability monitors using a bit of SQL and some principles from ML.
Monte Carlo Data

title: Top 5 Trends: What's Next in Data Annotation Tooling and Workflows?
summary:
Improved technologies and processes for data preparation are on the rise. iMerit, a leader in providing high-quality data, shares the latest in how annotation workflows, workforces, and tooling capabilities can scale with accuracy and precision.
// sponsored

title: Comprehensive Date-Time Handling for R
summary:
Clock is a new R package that provides a comprehensive set of tools for working with date-time data. Includes utilities for parsing, formatting, arithmetic, rounding, extraction/updating of individual components, and new data types that help handle time zones.
Tidyverse| Davis Vaughan

title: Dimension reduction 2
summary:
Last week Claus Wilke shared an awesome slide deck about Principal Components Analysis (PCA). In this second part, he covers those times when regular PCA doesn't cut it. In case you missed it, here's Part 1 >>
Claus O. Wilke

title: Alternatives to a Log Scale
summary:
For the most part, log scales are really hard for non-scientific audiences to interpret. Here's a think-through of alternative ways to present data where log scales are commonly used. This is short and useful.
Stephanie Evergreen

title: Matrix Multiplication Inches Closer to Mythic Goal
summary:
A recent paper set the fastest record yet for multiplying two matrices. But it also marks the end of the line for a method researchers have relied on for decades to make improvements.
Quanta Magazine | Kevin Hartnett

title: Platforms vs. PhDs: How tech giants court and crush the people who study them
summary:
Although scraping public websites may be legal, Big Tech writes the rules for its own platforms. Some of those rules are being challenged in courts but meanwhile, the dynamic between Big Tech platforms and the people who study how those platforms use data is rife with tension.
Protocol | Issie Lapowsky

title: How to get to a higher-performing model faster, with active learning
summary: Curious what active learning could do for your model? Alegion breaks down the three major advantages to using active learning as part of your model development. Alegion helps customers with their model development when models need to get better and better at granular classification of low confidence instances to get to higher quality, faster. Learn more.

title: How We Built a Context-Specific Bidding System for Etsy Ads
summary:
This is a great post that walks through the considerations and algorithms of Etsy's online ad platform. Here's how they moved from making batch predictions once per day to dynamic predictions up to 12,000 times per second. The post is easy to follow and gets into details that aren't often shared.
Etsy | Code as Craft

title: Unit testing Python code in Jupyter notebooks
summary:
Whether you are a unit testing purist or you just want to sprinkle a few tests into your notebooks, here are a few options to consider. Includes links and sample code for each approach.
Matt Wright

title: The ghosts in the data
summary:
Implicit knowledge is knowledge that exists within expert communities but isn't written down. To be effective, it's key to understand what that knowledge is and how to access it. In her latest post, Vicki Boykis explores this "ghost" knowledge in the data world.
Vicki Boykis

title: GPT-3 Powers the Next Generation of Apps
summary:
GPT-3 launched just nine months ago and already, it powers more than 300 applications with semantic search, summarization, sentiment analysis, content generation, translation, and more. Here's an update from the project including platform improvements and a selection of applications that show its range of capabilities.
OpenAI

title: R vs. Python vs. Julia
summary:
This article isn't about which is better. If you want to write code that's efficient, which language should you choose?
Daniel Moura

title: Create Your Own VS Code Themes
summary:
Create your own or install a theme from the gallery with this theme builder for VS Code.
Theme Studio

title: Dimension reduction 1
summary:
This set of slides is an awesome introduction to Principal Components Analysis (PCA). The examples are easy to follow, there are worthwhile references at the end and, for R users, there's sample code too.
Claus O. Wilke

title: Elevation Scan
summary:
Elegant approach for visualizing max/mean elevation across the world. This is a work of art in code.
Observable | Nicolas Lambert

title: What Data Can't Do
summary:
"Whenever you try to force the real world to do something that can be counted, unintended consequences abound..."
New Yorker | Hannah Fry

title: Why the Pandemic Experts Failed
summary:
Every day for the past year, the COVID Tracking Project collected COVID-19 data for the United States. In this retrospective, two of the project's founders share what they discovered about U.S. healthcare data, along with key insights about data usage in general. This is a great article that shows how the system "largely worked as designed." And that's a problem.
The Atlantic

title: Your Face Is Not Your Own
summary:
When the U.S. Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in 2019 that it's legal to scrape data from public websites, it was hard to know what dangers might be enabled for emerging technologies. It's early days still but Clearview AI is an interesting — and scary — player to watch.
New York Times

title: A Modern Data Architecture, co-written with Sisu
summary: In this guide, we’ll cover why modern data stacks scale better and when you should update your stack.

title: Toward Better Data Culture From First Principles
summary:
Uber collects and processes petabytes of data everyday for things like route optimization, fraud detection, pricing, and experimentation. This post explores issues they encountered while scaling and how they successfully approached them using First Principles.
Uber Engineering

title: Effective Data Monitoring
summary:
If you're using alerts to monitor data quality issues, this post is for you. Here are ten tactics for reducing noise and optimizing your data alerts.
Anomalo | Jeremy Stanley

title: Experimentation at Tubi
summary:
Tubi's experimentation culture has been instrumental to the company's success. Over the past 3 years, the rate of experimentation at Tubi has increased 18x and one in three machine learning experiments in the last quarter showed KPI impact. This post explores how they do it.
Tubi Engineering Blog

title: How To Make Smarter Data-driven Decisions at Scale
summary:
Join this webinar to learn how fellow data and analytics leaders leverage centralized data through modernization and democratization initiatives. You’ll hear first-hand experiences using data as a strategic asset to drive smarter decisions – like when to launch new product offerings, where to automate manual processes, and how to earn customer trust.

title: New edition of Data Journalism Handbook
summary:
This just-released edition of the Data Journalism Handbook offers a diverse collection of perspectives on how data journalism is done around the world. In its 54 chapters, leading researchers and practitioners offer both practical insight and critical reflection. Follow the links to download an open-access version or to purchase it in print.
Liliana Bounegru

title: Which color scale to use when visualizing data
summary:
When visualizing data, you’re almost always working with color. This first post in a new series offers a great overview of color scales, how they're important, and why they're not as clear-cut as you might think. This is an awesome series with lots of examples and references.
Chartable | Lisa Charlotte Rost

title: ggplot Wizardry: Tricks and Secrets for Beautiful Plots in R
summary:
This popular talk from the recent Outlier Conference includes a hands-on tutorial, slides, code, and a recording of the 20 minute presentation.
GitHub | OutlierConf2021

title: How Facebook got addicted to spreading misinformation
summary:
Artificial Intelligence at scale depends on vast resources of data and talent that few organizations are able to pull together. Facebook does it but an organization as large as Facebook is easily tangled in complex internal dynamics that can hinder efforts for "Responsible AI ." This is a well-researched, epic article that explores how Facebook failed.
MIT Technology Review | Karen Hao

title: Gartner cites ‘glut of innovation’ in DS and ML
summary:
A recent Gartner report evaluates DSML platforms and, among other things, cites a “glut of compelling innovations.”  Here are the highlights.
VentureBeat | Louis Columbus

title: Need high-quality training data for ML & AI?
summary: Let your data teams focus on core research and business objectives while our in-house, advanced workforce handles the data annotation work for you. iMerit is trusted by Microsoft, Autodesk, and TripAdvisor for their computer vision and natural language processing data annotation needs. title: How to Write Better
summary: Eugene Yan consistently writes some of the most useful data science articles you'll find on the web. His posts are well researched and his writing is super clear and organized. In this two-part series, he offers his framework for thinking through and organizing writing projects —  especially as they relate to technical and design docs:

title: We Failed to Set Up a Data Catalog 3x. Here’s Why.
summary:
When the data team at Atlan decided to create a data catalog, they thought it would be easy. After three failed attempts over five years, they finally got it right. This post gives a high-level view of each iteration, how they approached it, and lessons learned along the way.
Humans of Data Blog | Prukalpa Sankar

title: Pattern-based spatial analysis
summary:
Pattern-based spatial analysis allows for spatial search, change detection, and clustering of areas with similar patterns. It's commonly used with satellite imagery for environmental monitoring, real estate planning, healthcare analytics, etc. This five part introduction is easy to follow and includes lots of examples, code snippets and screenshots.
Jakub Nowosad

title: Instrumental variables analysis for non-economists
summary:
Instrumental Variables analysis is a popular way to do causal inference but it's often explained using concepts that are mostly familiar to economists. In this introduction, Chris Said uses a visual approach to explain concepts in a way that tends to be more intuitive for data scientists and engineers.
Chris Said

title: Defensible Machine Learning
summary:
ML companies have the potential to revolutionize business but they're hard to scale and they look and feel different from typical software businesses. Here's a simple framework to help founders and investors think through three types of defensible machine learning companies. Especially if you're thinking about ML startups, this is a must-read.
Base Case Capital | Ankur Goyal, Alana Anderson

title: Luminaire - A hands-off Anomaly Detection Library
summary:
Luminaire is a python package that provides ML-driven solutions for monitoring time series data. Luminaire provides anomaly detection and forecasting capabilities that incorporate correlational and seasonal patterns as well as uncontrollable variations in the data over time.
GitHub | Zillow

title: image2csv
summary:
image2csv is a Python application converts images of an array of numbers to corresponding csv files. In other words, take a screenshot of a table and image2csv will create a csv file using the data in the table.
GitHub | artperrin

title: Data Pricing: from Economics to Data Science
summary:
This survey paper explores ways to systematically assess the value of data. At 82 pages, it's not a light read but it's well-organized and is a fantastic resource for anyone interested in putting a monetary value on data products. For a good introduction, check out Ben Lorica's recent interview with the author on The Data 
Exchange Podcast.
arXiv | Jian Pei

title: How to send an 'E mail' - from 1984 via Database
summary:
This short video that's been bouncing around the web this week offers a glimpse into the world of email in 1984. Ultimately, it shows why email wasn't a big thing back then! We've come a long way since 1984 but then again, if you watch closely when he enters his password, you might think that some things haven't changed much at all.
YouTube | ThamesTv

title: Measuring Trends in Artificial Intelligence
summary:
The 2021 AI Index Report aims to "be the world’s most credible and authoritative source for data and insights about AI." The report is organized into seven chapters that cover a variety of topics including things like R&D, the Economy, Education, Ethics, Diversity, and National Policies. Start with the short Takeaways section at the beginning.
Stanford Institute for Human-Centered Artificial Intelligence

title: New Algorithm Breaks Speed Limit for Solving Linear Equations
summary:
By harnessing randomness, a new algorithm achieves a fundamentally novel — and faster — way of performing one of the most basic computations in math and computer science.
Quanta Magazine

summary: Get a dramatic throughput for the most demanding analytics, inference, or training workloads with AMAX’s high density NVIDIA® A100 GPU server. Experience the most powerful end-to-end AI & HPC data center platform with a test drive now!

title: What Your Data Team is Using: The Analytics Stack
summary:
Great overview of a modern analytics stack. Includes a reasonable breakdown for how to think about the stack layers and commonly used tools for each layer. This is a highly recommended high-level view.
Technically | Justin Gage

title: Data vault: new weaponry in your data science toolkit
summary:
Data Vault is a modeling technique for capturing historical data that makes it easy to "time travel" for historical states of truth. In this post, Bas Vlaming describes how Data Vault works and how it enables the data science team at the online grocer called "Picnic."
Picnic Blog | Bas Vlaming

title: Learn About Transformers: A Recipe
summary:
Transformers have been key for the rapid advances in natural language processing over the past few years and they're becoming increasingly important for vision tasks as well. The learning path presented here introduces a "recipe" of blog posts, videos, papers, and code repos for learning about the world of transformers.
Elvis's Blog

title: How To Make Smarter Data-driven Decisions at Scale
summary:
Join this webinar to learn how fellow data and analytics leaders leverage centralized data through modernization and democratization initiatives. You’ll hear first-hand experiences using data as a strategic asset to drive smarter decisions – like when to launch new product offerings, where to automate manual processes, and how to earn customer trust.

title: Bambi - BAyesian Model-Building Interface in Python
summary:
Bambi is a high-level Bayesian model-building interface written in Python. It's built on top of the PyMC3 probabilistic programming framework, and is designed to make it extremely easy to fit mixed-effects models.
GitHub | bambinos

title: The Violin Plot
summary:
This introduction to violin plots includes lots of examples that make it easy to see how they work and why they're so popular. Follow the links at the end for code samples and further reading.
Stela Yordanova

title: The Data Visualizations Behind COVID Skepticism
summary:
How is it that the U.S. has become so polarized over its understanding of COVID-19 risks? A group from MIT looked at a half million tweets, over 41,000 visualizations, and spent six months lurking in anti-mask Facebook groups. In this interactive report, they show how data visualization has become a battleground.
MIT Visualization Group

title: A View Of The Future Of Our Data
summary:
What if instead of giving our data away, there were "data coalitions" that acted as brokers and made sure that data was used on behalf of its members’ interests? For now, it's an optimistic idea but it could become real in the not too distant future. Here's how that could look.
Noema Magazine | Matt Prewitt

title: Can Auditing Eliminate Bias from Algorithms?
summary:
Algorithmic auditing is an emerging industry that examines black box algorithms to ensure that they're free from bias. Given the persistent issues around bias and the high stakes involved, you might think that auditing would be a welcome solution. Not exactly.
The Markup

title: Gartner Top 10 Data and Analytics Trends for 2021
summary:
From artificial intelligence to small data and graph technology, here are 10 key trends that data and analytics leaders should consider for 2021.
Gartner

title: This Asset Class is Returning 13.6% Annually
summary:
84% of ultra-high-net worth individuals collect art, according to a 2019 Deloitte survey. It makes sense—contemporary art returned 13.6% per year over the last 25 years vs. 8.9% for the S&P 500. Masterworks let you invest in million-dollar works by artists like Basquiat and Banksy at a fraction of the cost. Data 
Elixir Subscribers can sign up and skip the 17,500 person waitlist today.*

title: Visualizing Data Timeliness at Airbnb
summary:
In a large organization like Airbnb, data that isn't available when it's expected to be available can adversely affect multiple teams and products. As part of its series on data quality, this post walks through the issues of data timeliness at Airbnb and the considerations for an internal tool that tracks timeliness and lineage across pipelines. This is a great post with lots of  screenshots from their "SLA Tracker" tool.
Airbnb Engineering & Data Science

title: Feature Stores - A Hierarchy of Needs
summary:
Eugene Yan's latest post is a fantastic introduction to feature stores. It's organized as a "hierarchy of needs," which makes it easy to understand what feature stores provide exactly, and which capabilities may be useful for your particular needs. Includes lots of examples.
Eugene Yan

title: Is Facebook's "Prophet" the Time-Series Messiah?
summary:
Facebook prophet is a popular package for time series prediction and has been downloaded nearly 14 million times.  But does it work?
Microprediction | Peter Cotton

title: How to break a model in 20 days
summary:
What can go wrong with a machine learning model in production? In this tutorial, learn how to train a model, simulate deployment, and analyze its gradual decay.
Evidently AI

title: Map of my personal data infrastructure
summary:
This "data liberation infrastructure" map is for the seriously self-quantified. It's part crazy, part geeky, and part awesome. The write-up includes links to posts that elaborate on different parts of the map, along with the scripts and tools that are used to maintain it.
beepb00p

title: Can Algorithms Learn to Fight Wars Ethically?
summary:
The U.S. Pentagon is spending a lot of money to develop advanced AI capabilities for the military. AI may be better at making fast decisions but when it comes to moral decisions, it could be a nightmare. There's a lot at stake and the issues are anything but black and white.
Washington Post

title: External data should be part of your data strategy
summary:
A 2018 report found that the most analytically mature organizations use a variety of data sources from outside of their organization. Third-party data is out there to find and use. Here's how to get started.
MIT Sloan School of Management

title: Virtual event: Using third-party data to make smarter decisions
summary: Join this virtual event with Stephen Orban, author of Ahead in the Cloud and General Manager of AWS Data Exchange. He will lead a panel discussion with AWS customers to discuss the innovative techniques being used in data pipelines, with data analysis, and for data visualization. You will discover real-world initiatives and breakthroughs being enabled by third-party data.

title: Data Mesh 101: Everything You Need To Know
summary:
Great starting point for understanding all the excitement about data meshes. Follow the links for some of the best resources that explain what data meshes are, how they're useful and how to get started.
Monte Carlo Data | Barr Moses

title: Create privacy-preserving synthetic data for machine learning with SmartNoise
summary:
Differential privacy promises significantly higher privacy protection than data anonymization techniques and it could be transformative in fields like medicine and economics. This post introduces the technique and how it's becoming the gold standard for data protection. Includes links to a detailed white paper and an open-source toolkit.
Microsoft Open Source Blog

title: Autodata: Automating common data operations
summary:
A lot of tasks in a data science workflow can be automated. In this post, Adam Marcus explores the landscape of open-source autodata tools and how it may evolve.
Adam Marcus

title: Patterns: Publishing cross-disciplinary data science outputs
summary:
There is more to data science than just the research article. Patterns publishes all the outputs of data science research including software, data sets, algorithms and infrastructures. Shine a spotlight on your work; submit your paper today. 
// sponsored

title: MindsDB
summary:
MindsDB is a predictive AI layer for existing databases that allows you to develop, train and deploy state-of-the-art ML models using SQL queries. This project is growing fast and there's a lot to explore here.
GitHub | mindsdb

title: kglab: Graph-Based Data Science
summary:
The kglab package provides an abstraction layer in Python for building knowledge graphs. It leverages idiomatic Python for common use cases in data science and data engineering work that require graph data. If you're just getting started or need help, see the Resources section.
DerwinAI

title: DSPods
summary:
Nice collection of podcasts about data science, machine learning, and ML engineering. As of this morning, there are 24 active podcasts on this page, covering a wide range of topics. Updated daily.
DSPods

title: D3 Turns 10
summary:
Ten years ago, the popular data viz library known as D3 was introduced to the world and empowered a new generation of experts to work with data in ways that weren't possible before. This anniversary post looks back at the stories and the people that brought D3 to life.  For a gallery and Getting Started guide, see the D3 
tag in the Data Elixir Archives.
Observable | Melody Meckfessel

title: Data visualization using ggplot2 (intermediate)
summary:
Take your ggplot2 skills to the next level with these new workshop materials. This is well organized, includes a linked index, and there are lots of code snippets with screenshots to make it useful as a reference. For introductory materials, follow the links at the top.
RPubs | Ben Bond-Lamberty

title: How to build data literacy in your company
summary:
A recent Gartner survey found that poor data literacy in an organization is one of the top three barriers to building a strong data and analytics team. Meanwhile, a survey by Accenture showed that most employees aren't confident in their data skills. This post explores how companies should think about data literacy and develop it as an asset.
MIT Sloan School of Management

title: Publish your data science research in Patterns
summary: Patterns is a new gold open access journal that promotes all types of cross- disciplinary data science research and outputs. We bring together researchers to solve key scientific problems that cross domain boundaries. Publish your work with us today!

title: Building the Modern Data Stack
summary:
For organizations that are leveling-up their data stack, figuring out which combination of tools to use is complicated. This post explores the issues and offers a framework with specific suggestions to simplify the process. Includes insights from interviews with hundreds of data teams.
Raghu Murthy, Founder and CEO of Datacoral

title: Supercharging Apache Superset
summary:
Apache Superset is an open-source data exploration platform that's designed to be visual and easy to use. It started as a hackathon project at Airbnb, joined Apache as an Incubator project, and has since grown to be a mature BI tool for the enterprise. This is an awesome introduction to the project and how Airbnb has customized it for BI at scale.
Airbnb Engineering & Data Science

title: Data Observability, Part II: How to Build Your Own Data Quality Monitors Using SQL
summary:
In this SQL tutorial, Barr Moses and Ryan Kearns show how data teams can use metadata gleaned from schema and lineage to understand the root cause of data anomalies. In other words, this tutorial will help you contextualize the "why" and "how" behind broken data pipelines.
Barr Moses, CEO of Monte Carlo and Ryan Kearns

title: WTF Python! 😱
summary:
Strain your brain with this collection of code snippets that demonstrate some counter-intuitive and lesser-known features of Python.
GitHub | Satwik Kansal

title: Ploomber
summary:
Ploomber makes it easy to turn your notebooks, scripts or Python functions into a reproducible data pipeline for data science or ML.
GitHub | ploomber

title: Math Inspector
summary:
Math Inspector is a visual programming environment for scientific computing based on numpy and scipy. Imagine web inspector, except for math and with block coding.
Math Inspector

title: How Can We Fix the Data Science Talent Shortage?
summary:
New grads with data science skills are getting a cool reception from a job market that's supposedly hot for data scientists. This post explores the reasons why, what employers are really looking for, and how people new to the field should approach it.
Springboard | Kindra Cooper

title: Patterns, Predictions, and Actions
summary:
Here's a new machine learning gem that's worth downloading. This is a graduate level text that covers the foundations of prediction and pattern recognition, moving from decision theory to supervised learning to causality and reinforcement learning. Intended for readers who have some experience with probability, calculus, and linear algebra.
arXiv | Moritz Hardt, Benjamin Recht

title: Modern Data Science with R
summary:
The second edition of Modern Data Science with R is coming out in March but the Bookdown version is already available for free online.
Benjamin S. Baumer, Daniel T. Kaplan, and Nicholas J. Horton

title: Data Elixir Advanced Article and Topic Search
summary: Data Elixir has a new search page! That may not sound interesting but there's a lot more to it than an input box for keywords. Using the Polymer Search Insights platform, the latest 6 months of Data Elixir issues have been catalogued, tagged, and cross-referenced to make it interesting to browse and easy to find something specific. Check it out and reply back to this email if you have suggestions. More to come!

title: The Hard Lessons of Modeling the Pandemic
summary:
It's been a hard year for COVID-19 modelers. The public seems to think that models are oracles of the future but the reality is far different. That's created a lot of tension and is changing how public-facing modelers work and communicate results. This is a worthwhile longread.
Quanta Magazine | Jordana Cepelewicz

title: Find high quality data with Trove - Get $500 credit*
summary:
Trove is a new crowdsourcing marketplace from Microsoft where
developers can gather images for AI models from regular individuals,
responsibly sourced through licensing and privacy frameworks.
Get highly relevant and diverse images from real people, for your specific scenario and use case.
*Terms apply.

title: Causal design patterns for data analysts
summary:
Design patterns help you recognize problems and reuse proven solutions. They can save you time and help ensure that your work uses best practices. This post is a great introduction to causal analysis design that will help you develop an intuition for these kinds of problems.
Emily Riederer

title: Why ML algorithms are hard to tune and how to fix it
summary:
Linear combinations of losses may sound appealing, but oftentimes, that makes them hard to tune. This two-part post uses clear visuals to show the problem and then digs into an old NIPS paper (1988!) for a solution.
Engraved | Jonas Degrave, Ira Korshunova

title: Designing Experimentation Guardrails
summary:
Airbnb runs 1000's of experiments each week and those experiments affect internal teams differently. Experiments that have positive impacts for one team may have negative impacts for another and it's not always obvious how to weigh the trade-offs. Here's how Airbnb's Experiment Guardrails framework helps prevent negative impacts.
Airbnb Engineering & Data Science

title: Data Observability: The Next Monitoring Frontier
summary:
As data pipelines grow in complexity, monitoring tools are becoming increasingly important. Here's a look at the problems being solved and how solutions are evolving.
Clouded Judgement | Jamin Ball

title: The Anatomy of a Data Citation
summary:
Data citations are important for establishing trust and reproducibility but data isn't widely recognized as a "citable" source. Here's why it's important to cite data anyway, how it's different from other citations, and what, specifically, data citations should include.
ripeta

title: 2021: The year you make ML (and your job) easier
summary:
Make it easy to get your ML projects from experiment to production. Comet automatically tracks datasets, code changes, experimentation history and production models - all so you can focus on data science. Get started today with the free community edition.

title: data ⎰ describe
summary:
data-describe is a Python toolkit for Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA). It aims to accelerate data exploration and analysis by providing automated and polished analysis widgets.
GitHub | data-describe

title: SQLFluff
summary:
SQLFluff is an extensible and modular linter that works with a variety of dialects and is designed to help you write clean SQL and catch errors before they hit your database. It can auto-fix most linting errors too.
GitHub | SQLFluff

title: "Very few techies are trying to do the big hard things."
summary:
Many of the large tech companies have started "AI for Good" programs and claim they want to help solve big problems like climate change, sustainability, and social issues. Are they for real? And if so, what challenges do they face besides who's actually going to do the work?
Marc Winkelmann interviewing Clive Thompson

title: Seven Legal Questions for Data Scientists
summary:
From privacy and algorithmic bias to security and third-party dependencies, there are a lot of ways that data can get you in trouble. Thinking through the questions discussed in this article will help ensure that you and your organization stay aligned with the law.
O'Reilly Media | Patrick Hall and Ayoub Ouederni

title: What is a Feature Store?
summary:
Feature Stores manage the lifecycle of features that power ML applications. They enable data scientists to build features quickly and reliably, and provision them to production instantly. This post explains what a feature store is and describes its main components.
Tecton

title: Unsupervised Data Monitoring
summary:
In this first post in a new series, Jeremy Stanley shows how relying on rules to monitor data quality doesn't scale and why you should use unsupervised learning instead. The examples here are great and, if you're interested in data quality, this will definitely be a series to watch.
Anomalo | Jeremy Stanley

title: Building a team of internal R packages
summary:
If your organization has started building its own packages, this post by Emily Riederer offers a great approach for designing and tying together an ecosystem of internal tools. Using the jobs-to-be-done framework as a guide, she explores strategies for API design, docs, testing, and more.
Emily Riederer

title: ML Theory with bad drawings
summary:
Nice introduction to machine learning concepts with lots of helpful diagrams along the way.
Windows on Theory | Boaz Barak

title: Recommending Articles With Help From Our Friends
summary:
It seems like a simple problem. Let readers select interests from a list of categories and then send them personalized content. But at scale, that quickly gets complicated. Here's how and what the New York Times learned from a different approach using machine learning.
NYT Open | Joyce Xu

title: AMAX: Experience the Fastest Solutions for AI
summary:
Take a test drive on AMAX’s GPU-accelerated server solutions with the latest NVIDIA Ampere GPU architecture to kick start your most demanding analytics, inference, or training workloads with access to AI Expertise for a seamless testing integration. Experience the most powerful end-to-end AI & HPC data center platform now!

title: Building a data science startup
summary:
Interested in turning a data science side project into a small startup? Listen to this discussion with four current founders to learn about some ripe opportunities and key skills you need.
TalkPython['Podcast']

title: Wanted: Data Scientists with Technical Brilliance AND Business Sense
summary:
Technical skills are important but when it comes to making big impacts, business intuition is key. In this post, Alok Gupta describes how entrepreneurial data scientists at DoorDash approach problems differently and get more done, faster.
DoorDash Engineering

title: Density Plots
summary:
Scatterplots and line charts often encounter performance and overplotting issues as the amount of data increases. Density plots are an alternative that can work better for larger volumes of data.  Here's how they work, including a library and interactive examples to play with.
Oberservable | Twitter Open Source

title: Julia Adoption Keeps Climbing; Python Challenger?
summary:
Julia is hot. In the last three years, the number of active users has more than doubled and in 2020, the number of available packages rose to ~4800. In this article, John Russell explores Julia's rapid rise and how it compares to other languages. Includes useful links throughout.
HPC Wire | John Russell

title: Advance your career with a degree for future leaders
summary: Consider Minerva’s Master of Science in Decision Analysis for a unique, online experience designed for working professionals. Regardless of your industry, Minerva can help you develop leadership and advanced data analysis skills to make data-informed decisions and advance your career. Learn more >>

title: Bayesian statistics and modelling
summary:
This Primer offers a great introduction to Bayesian statistics and modeling. It covers key aspects of determining prior distributions, likelihood functions and posterior distributions in addition to applications of the method across disciplines.
Nature Reviews Methods Primers

title: Generating SQL with {dbplyr} and sqlfluff
summary:
Great ideas here for R users who need to generate SQL code. In this step-by-step tutorial, Emily Riederer shows how to use the tidyverse's data wrangling vocabulary as a preprocessor for elegant SQL scripts. The resulting scripts are less error-prone and easier to read and write.
Emily Riederer

title: Machine Learning: The Great Stagnation
summary:
What counts for innovation anyway? This is an insightful essay that's sure to get your hackles up.
Mark Saroufim

title: 2021: The year you make ML (and your job) easier
summary:
Make it easy to get your ML projects from experiment to production. Comet automatically tracks datasets, code changes, experimentation history and production models - all so you can focus on data science. Get started today with the free community edition.

title: Introducing CatalyzeX: A Browser Extension for ML
summary:
CatalyzeX is a browser extension that automatically shows you open-source code for machine learning and AI papers that you come across on Google, Arxiv, Twitter, Scholar, and other websites.
Hackernoon

title: Best-of Machine Learning with Python
summary:
This curated collection of open-source Python libraries is very well organized and updated weekly. Projects are organized into sections that cover things like ML frameworks, visualization, probability & statistics, time series, recommender systems, distributed ML, and  lots more.
GitHub | ml-tooling

title: A retrospective of NeurIPS 2020
summary:
More than 23,000 people were at NeurIPS 2020 but in case you missed it, this collection of notes and highlights is a great starting point for what you missed. This post covers a wide variety of selected talks, is well-written, and includes links to key resources along the way.
FELD | Rany Keddo

title: We Don't Need Data Scientists, We Need Engineers
summary:
This is a useful exploration of data skills that are in high demand among YC startups. YC is important here because it tends to be a forward-thinking incubator whose alumni companies span many industries. The  bottom line — go for solid engineering skills with a bent towards data. For more, check out the discussion on Hacker News >> 
Mihail Eric

title: Data science as an atomic habit
summary:
Data science moves fast but keep in mind that no one is born a master. Mastery comes from the cultivation of small, sustainable habits. It's going to suck for awhile but to keep growing, create a life that systematically supports your practice. Slowly. One step at a time...
Malcolm Barrett

title: Medicine's Machine Learning Problem
summary:
Data science offers the potential to fundamentally alter medicine but despite the promise, biased datasets and unaccountable algorithms threaten to further disempower patients. 
Boston Review | Rachel Thomas

title: Inside India’s booming dark data economy
summary:
In India, the black market for data resembles markets for wholesale vegetables and smuggled goods. Customers are encouraged to buy in bulk, and the variety of what’s available is mind-boggling.
Rest of World

title: Machine learning is going real-time
summary:
In her latest post, Chip Huyen explores the current state of real-time, online machine learning including use-cases, solutions, and challenges. After interviews with about a dozen companies, she concludes that "machine learning is going real-time, whether you’re ready or not."
Chip Huyen

title: 2021: The year you make ML (and your job) easier
summary: Make it easy to get your ML projects from experiment to production. Comet automatically tracks datasets, code changes, experimentation history and production models - all so you can focus on data science. Get started today with the free community edition.

title: The value of p
summary:
What we lose if we abandon p values.
Richard D. Morey

title: NumPy Illustrated
summary:
This visual guide is a great introduction to NumPy and has gotten a lot of attention around the web recently. It builds on a previous article by Jay Alammar and covers a broad range of operations including vectors, matrices, and high dimensional operations.
Lev Maximov

title: Top 10 Python libraries of 2020
summary:
Tryolabs' annual list of top Python libraries is consistently a must-read post. This year's list is tailored for data science and ML and includes tools for high-dimensional plotting, config management, forecasting, command line interfaces, productivity, outlier detection, and more.
Tryolabs

title: Uncertainty Toolbox
summary:
This Python toolkit provides standard metrics to quantify and compare uncertainty estimates from ML methods. It  also offers intuition for these metrics, produces visualizations, and implements simple "re-calibration" procedures to help improve the uncertainties. This is well-documented and includes a collection of linked references.
GitHub | uncertainty-toolbox

title: JupyterLab 3.0 is released!
summary:
Jupyter 3.0 is a major release that includes some key features including a visual debugger, a table of content for notebooks, multiple display languages, and a much improved extension system. See this announcement post for details.
Jupyter | Jeremy Tuloup

title: 2020: A Year Full of Amazing AI papers- A Review
summary:
This curated list of the latest breakthroughs in AI include short video explanations, links to in-depth articles, and code.
GitHub | Louis-François Bouchard

title: ⚽ Analytics 2020 Review
summary:
Awesome roundup of ⚽ analytics content from 2020. Covers research papers, blog posts, podcasts, talks, Python libraries, datasets, and more!
Jan Van Haaren

title: You Can’t Escape Hyperparameters and Latent Variables: ML as a Software Engineering Enterprise
summary:
Great "keynote" from NeurIPS 2020 about the past, present and future of ML research — especially as it pertains to algorithmic bias. It's 45 minutes but don't let that deter you. This is a well-paced presentation that's full of insightful conversations with researchers, engineers, and data scientists. Starts at 29:04.
NeurIPS 2020 | Charles Isbell

title: Learn R, Python, and SQL with Dataquest, the data science platform recommended by 97% of learners.
summary: No video lectures, no fill-in-the-blank quizzes. Learn through high-quality, step-by-step courses developed by a team of data experts. Sign up for free to start analyzing data today -- all in your browser.

title: Easier Code Reviews For Jupyter Notebooks
summary:
The raw content of Jupyter Notebooks is a mix of dissimilar source code, Markdown, and HTML, making Jupyter notoriously challenging for code reviews. This tutorial shows how to use an open-source utility called nbautoexport to simplify the process.
DrivenData

title: Why Some Models Leak Data
summary:
Machine learning models use large amounts of data, some of which can be sensitive. If the models aren't trained correctly, sometimes that data is inadvertently revealed. This interactive essay shows how.
PAIR Explorables | Adam Pearce and Ellen Jiang

title: Data Catalogs Are Dead; Long Live Data Discovery
summary:
Data catalogs aren't cutting it anymore when it comes to metadata management and data governance. Here's how data discovery can help.
Monte Carlo Blog | Barr Moses and Debashis Saha

title: Financial Times Data Platform: From zero to hero
summary:
Great walk-through of the evolution of the Financial Times data platform. Includes detailed timelines and decisions along the way.
FT Product & Technology Blog

title: End-to-end Production ML Monitoring
summary:
This post bills itself as a "deep dive" into production machine learning monitoring but it's organized in a way that also makes it easy to get a high level view of what ML monitoring is all about. Covers outlier detectors, drift detectors, metrics servers and explainers.
Alejandro Saucedo

title: AMAX: Revolutionary GPU solutions for data insights at deskside
Advanced Data Science 2020
summary:
This GitBook accompanies a semester-long course that focuses on the "hard" part of data science. The assumption is that you already have a background in statistics, programming and the basics of reproducible research. The focus in this course is on synthesizing those tools into a data analysis and then communicating that analysis to an audience.
Johns Hopkins University | Jeff Leek and Roger D. Peng

title: Papers with Code is Expanding
summary:
Papers with Code recently launched new sites for statistics, math, computer science, and more. Use these sites to discover new projects and/or sync your code to show on arXiv. See the post for details.
Papers with Code Blog

title: Blob Opera
summary:
Blog Opera is a surprisingly addictive machine learning experiment by David Li in collaboration with Google Arts and Culture. Nothing to learn here. Just a fun machine learning toy to brighten up your holidays! ✨
Google Arts & Culture

title: Most important statistical ideas of the past 50 years?
summary:
This new paper explores eight major statistical ideas of the past 50 years, including overviews and discussion of what they each have in common, how they differ and what to expect over the next few decades.
arXiv | Andrew Gelman, Aki Vehtari

title: Join the data science community at SIAM - new journal, book series, conference, and activity group!
summary: Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) has launched a collection of new data science resources! The most recent additions are the SIAM Activity Group on Data Science (a place to network and collaborate!) and the SIAM Journal on Mathematics of Data Science. Learn more about SIAM’s data science offerings and stay connected to the community.

title: Airbnb-quality data for all
summary:
Great follow-on article to the recent data quality series from Airbnb. In this article, Jeremy Stanley, founder of Anomalo, shows how to build and maintain high quality data "without raising billions."
Anomalo | Jeremy Stanley

title: Machine Learning model governance at scale
summary:
The dynamic nature of machine learning makes model governance particularly challenging — especially at scale. This is a best-practices article from Microsoft that explores the issues and approaches.
Data Science at Microsoft

title: (Re-)introducing Distill for R Markdown
summary:
Distill is a package for R Markdown that makes it easy to create technical articles, websites, and blogs in the style of the Distill Machine Learning Journal. Output is clean, interactive and engaging. Here are the highlights for the new 1.0 release, including links to key resources.
RStudio | Alison Hill and JJ Allaire

title: RipTable
summary:
High performance 64 bit python analytics engine for numpy arrays with multi-threaded support. Enhances or replaces numpy or pandas and claims it can crunch numbers 1.5 to 10 times faster.
GitHub | rtosholdings

title: Looking to Annotate Your Video Data?
summary:
Alegion just opened up its powerful video annotation capabilities for self-serve. Label your video with complete end-to-end control. Upload, configure, and label with speed, accuracy, rich annotation, ML efficiencies, real-time playback and download your annotated data, all on your time.
// sponsored

title: 2020’s Top AI & Machine Learning Research Papers
summary:
These short summaries of recent AI and Machine Learning research papers cover a wide variety of authors, topics and venues. Includes key points, diagrams and links for each paper.
TOPBOTS

title: A ggplot2 Tutorial for Beautiful Plotting in R
summary:
Awesome ggplot2 tutorial with lots of examples. Includes a linked Table of Contents and useful resources at the end. Worth bookmarking.
Cédric Scherer

title: Why use a radial data visualization?
summary:
Radial visualizations include circular layouts like pie charts, circular trees, sunbursts and weather wheels. They're an efficient way to present data but they can also be counter-productive. Here's a visual orientation of circular visualization options, why you might use them and the cases when clearly, there are better alternatives.
Observable | Kerry Rodden

title: "It will change everything"
summary:
DeepMind is now far beyond games like Chess and Go. In its latest breakthrough, AlphaFold has been recognized as a solution to one of biology's grand challenges — the “protein folding problem.” Here's a great overview of the accomplishment and why it's such a big deal.
Nature

title: Find Your Next Job Through Vettery
summary: Connect with hiring managers from actively hiring startups and Fortune 500 companies that are using Vettery to grow their tech teams. Create a profile today to get interview requests as early as next week. Oh, and did we mention it’s free for job-seekers?

title: Data Quality at Airbnb: Part 2 - A New Gold Standard
summary:
In this second post of a series, Vaughn Quoss walks through the approach that Airbnb uses to ensure data quality throughout the organization. This post focuses on identifying data quality issues and the development of a data certification process called "Midas."
Airbnb Engineering & Data Science

title: Least squares as springs
summary:
'Regression, principal components, machine learning... it's all just springs pulling the model toward the data.  Why don't we learn it this way?!'
Joshua Loftus

title: Replicate - Version Control for Machine Learning
summary:
Replicate is an open-source Python library that helps you keep track of ML experiments. Just add two lines to your training code and then Replicate will start tracking everything: code, hyperparameters, training data, weights, metrics, Python dependencies, etc.
GitHub | replicate

title: Bodywork Machine Learning
summary:
Bodywork is an open-source machine learning operations (MLOps) framework, targeted at automating the training and deployment of Python ML models on Kubernetes.
Bodywork

title: The State of Open Data 2020
summary:
Figshare's annual report on open data summarizes the survey results of 4500 researchers regarding their practices and challenges in sharing data in 2020. This covers a lot of ground and includes lots of interview snippets and visuals that give context and meaning to the results.
Digital Science

title: Challenges in Deploying ML: a Survey of Case Studies
summary:
This survey paper extracts practical considerations from recent case studies of a variety of ML applications and is organized into sections that correspond to stages of a typical machine learning workflow: from data management and model learning to verification and deployment.
arXiv | Andrei Paleyes, Raoul-Gabriel Urma, Neil D. Lawrence

title: Scented Candles: An unexpected victim of COVID-19
summary:
Apparently, "There are angry ladies all over Yankee Candle’s site reporting that none of the candles they just got had any smell at all." Kate Petrova dives in with some fun data exploration.
Twitter | @kate_ptrv

title: What Is the Best Strategy to Deploy a Vaccine?
summary:
COVID-19 is especially lethal for older adults and those with other health problems. Young adults are more likely to recover but tend to be big spreaders of the disease. That creates two conflicting priorities for the mathematicians. Should they prevent deaths or slow transmission?
Undark | Jill Neimark

title: Future-Proof Your Career, While You Work
summary: The Global Master of Management Analytics from Smith School of Business at Queen’s University is a 12-month program that can be taken from anywhere in the world.  Master the essential strategies for applying analytics to business needs in this ground-breaking program.

title: Dynamic Data Testing
summary:
Data is rarely static and for the most part, your tests shouldn't be either. This is a super useful post that explores the issues and introduces a framework for deciding how to test – from static tests that can be written in SQL, to dynamic tests that require statistics or ML.
Anomalo | Jeremy Stanley

title: Time-series ML tutorial using cryptocurrency data
summary:
Great machine learning tutorial using R and live data from the cryptocurrency markets. This is very well done and includes a hosted Jupyter notebook with sections for data prep, visualization, model validation, predictive modeling, evaluation, and more.
University of Colorado | Cryptocurrency Research

title: Experimentation with resource constraints
summary:
Different business models face different challenges and experimentation strategies that work in one model may not work in another. This post on the StitchFix blog starts out with a thought experiment about the foraging strategies of data-savvy squirrels...
MultiThreaded

title: The Four Jobs of the Data Scientist
summary:
If you find yourself thinking that part of this post doesn't apply to you, "then chances are that is where you are weak at data science."
Roger Peng

title: The Observable zealot
summary:
Observable recently announced a round of funding which helps ensure its role as a key data visualization platform for the web. As a celebratory response, a lot of Observable Notebooks were shared around the web this week. This one, in particular, captures why Observable is worth knowing. See the home page for a gallery of examples.
Observable | Fil

title: Alibi Detect
summary:
Alibi Detect is an open source Python library focused on outlier, adversarial and drift detection. The package aims to cover both online and offline detectors for tabular data, text, images and time series.
Seldon

title: ⚽ Football Analytics
summary:
Barça Innovation Hub's annual conference showcases the present and future of statistical modeling and analysis of sports data, especially as it pertains to ⚽. Scroll down the page and check out the research paper finalists for insights into the opportunities of this rapidly evolving field.
BARÇA Innovation Hub

title: COVID-19 Event Risk Assessment Planning Tool
summary:
If you're planning a big Thanksgiving this week, this dashboard shows the likelihood that you'll be sharing dinner with someone who has COVID-19. In the scheme of things, dinner might not be your biggest concern but adding air travel looks like a recipe for disaster.
Georgia Institute of Technology

title: Interview with Ashley Kramer, CPO/CMO, Sisense
summary:
Not long ago, Business Intelligence and Data Science were very different worlds but that's changing fast. In this interview, Ashley Kramer explores the Sisense platform and how the world of BI is increasingly colliding with data science.
Matt Turck's Blog

title: A Look At Next Generation Video Annotation
summary: Video annotation is becoming the new frontier of data labeling. Video annotation is complex - big video, rich video, deep video all come with numerous entities, relationships, ontologies and more. This white paper identifies key next generation solutions for big video giving data science the functionality, tooling and quality control to annotate their video ML projects.

title: Turning Metadata Into Insights with Databook
summary:
This post from Uber Engineering is the latest in a string of deep dives that explore in-house data discovery solutions. Uber's platform is called "Databook" and this is a comprehensive post that covers a variety of topics including motivations for the platform, how it's evolved, architecture, the data model, how discovery works and lots more.
Uber Engineering

title: How Prediction Markets Beat Polls
summary:
Prediction markets did pretty well in the 2020 election but they're far from perfect. In this post, Arpit Gupta takes a look at the successes and failings of the prediction markets versus the polls in this election cycle.
Arpit Gupta

title: 130 Machine Learning Projects Solved and Explained
summary:
This collection of hands-on tutorials walks through a wide variety of machine learning projects using Python.
Aman Kharwal

title: Data/Applied/Research Scientist, ML Engineer - What’s the Difference?
summary:
Great post that explores the various goals, skills, and deliverables of common "data science" job roles and what these evolving titles mean for the industry and your team.
Eugene Yan

title: Future-Proof Your Career, While You Work
summary:
The Global Master of Management Analytics from Smith School of Business at Queen’s University is a 12-month program that can be taken from anywhere in the world.  Master the essential strategies for applying analytics to business needs in this ground-breaking program.

title: Pluto.jl
summary:
Pluto.jl was built from the ground up to be a fresh new notebook system, written in Julia. Pluto notebooks are stored as executable .jl files and they're reactive, which means that affected cells automatically update when functions or variables are changed.
GitHub | fonsp

title: Dagli: Faster and easier machine learning on the JVM
summary:
Dagli is a new open source ML library for JVM languages, like Java. It contains a comprehensive collection of statistical models and feature transformers that are ready to use out of the box. Dagli is intended to make it easy to write, revise and deploy production-ready models.
LinkedIn Engineering

title: COVID-19 Mobility Network Modeling
summary:
How effective are stay-at-home orders on slowing the spread of COVID-19? This new project uses smartphone data to model the mobility of 98 million people to track the spread of COVID-19, detect hotspots, and guide reopening strategies. Includes an interactive simulation, links to anonymized data and a paper preview.
Stanford

title: Data Feminism
summary:
This interview with Catherine D’Ignazio and Lauren Klein is a great introduction to their recent book, Data Feminism. Don't be fooled by the title. Their book covers broad questions about power and ethics in data science and has been getting rave reviews around the web.
PAIR Blog

title: A hypothesis is a liability
summary:
20 years ago, a psychology experiment showed that people tend to miss obvious things if they're specifically looking for something else. It was called a "selective attention test" and it's become a psychology classic. Now, a similar phenomenon has been shown to occur in data analysis. When given a specific hypothesis to test, 
students tended to miss the gorilla in the data.
Genome Biology

title: Future-Proof Your Career, While You Work
summary: The Global Master of Management Analytics from Smith School of Business at Queen’s University is a 12-month program that can be taken from anywhere in the world.  Master the essential strategies for applying analytics to business needs in this ground-breaking program.

title: Data Quality at Airbnb - Part 1: Rebuilding at Scale
summary:
Airbnb is widely known as a data-driven organization but it wasn't always that way. Just two years ago, the company made a deep commitment to data quality and embarked on a major rebuilding effort. This first in a series of posts explores the issues and the key components of what became Airbnb's Data Quality initiative.
Airbnb Engineering & Data Science Blog

title: Hierarchical Time Series With Prophet and PyMC3
summary:
When doing time-series modeling, it's not uncommon to want to make long-term predictions for multiple, related, time-series. This is a great talk that shows how to build a hierarchical version of Facebook’s Prophet package to do exactly that.
PyMCon | Matthijs Brouns

title: Free Webinar: The Power of Spreadsheets for Achieving a Data Driven Culture
summary:
Now that companies understand the importance of a data driven culture, leaders are searching for practical ways to reinforce this new mindset. Join Metis to learn how spreadsheets can help employees get comfortable with data and empower them to perform their own analysis without hand holding by your advanced analytics team.
// sponsored

title: Deepnote - A better data science notebook
summary:
Deepnote is a new type of notebook for data science that's Jupyter-compatible, has real-time collaboration and runs in the cloud. This introduction shows how it can help you work more efficiently.
Deepnote

title: Pointblank
summary:
The pointblank R package makes it easy to methodically validate your data whether in the form of data frames or as database tables. In addition to the validation tools, the package gives you the ability to stay up-to-date with the information that defines your tables.
GitHub | rich-iannone

title: Intro to Linear Algebra for Applied ML with Python
summary:
Great introduction to linear algebra, especially with regards to machine learning. This is very well-organized and includes a detailed list of linked topics, lots of diagrams, and links to useful resources around the web.

title: List of ML and DL Conferences in 2020 and 2021
summary:
Looking for a conference to attend, sponsor or submit a talk to? This latest list from Tryolabs includes 40 machine learning conferences around the world. Most have gone virtual and offer good discounts.

title: earth
summary:
Cameron Beccario's live weather application just got a major upgrade. What started as a small project to refresh the menu turned into a rewrite of nearly the entire site. This is one of the best applications you'll find for visualizing wind, waves, temperatures and more using weather data from around the world.
nullschool | Cameron Beccario

summary: Connect with hiring managers from startups to Fortune 500 companies that are actively using Vettery to grow their tech teams. Create a profile today to get interview requests as early as next week. Oh, and did we mention it’s free for job-seekers?

title: An Overview of Data Discovery Platforms
summary:
Great post by Eugene Yan about all the data discovery platforms out there. Here's an overview of the questions they each help answer, key features and how they compare. In addition to well-known proprietary platforms, he covers open-source solutions such as LinkedIn's DataHub, Lyft's Amundsen, Netflix's Metacat and Apache Atlas.
Eugene Yan

title: To apply AI for good, think form extraction
summary:
When people consider doing AI/ML-for-Good projects, they often think about use-cases for predictive models. But on a practical level, smart methods for extracting data from forms would do more for journalism, climate science, medicine, democracy etc. than almost any other application. Here's a great overview of the issues and opportunities.
Jonathan Stray

title: Mixed Models with R
summary:
This introduction to using mixed models in R covers the most common techniques with demonstration primarily via the lme4 package. Discussion includes extensions into generalized mixed models, Bayesian approaches, and more.
Michael Clark

summary:
Awesome interactive tool for learning how correlations work. Be sure to click the ⚙️ icon for options.
Kristoffer Magnusson

title: Orbit - Bayesian time series modeling and inference
summary:
Orbit is a Python package for time series modeling and inference using Bayesian sampling methods for model estimation. It provides a familiar and intuitive initialize-fit-predict interface for working with time series tasks, while utilizing probabilistic modeling under the hood via PyStan.
GitHub | Uber Open Source

title: TimescaleDB 2.0
summary:
TimescaleDB is an open-source database for time series data that looks like Postgres but is optimized for fast ingest and complex queries. With this major new release, TimescaleDB introduces the first multi-node, petabyte-scale relational database for time-series. This 2.0 post is a nice overview of the project and what you can do with it.
Timescale

title: Stories for Visual Studio Code
summary:
For VS Code users, Stories is a simple way of sharing code snippets. This is a free extension that's gaining traction fast.

GitHub | Jason Timm

title: Election Forecast Correlations
summary:
Awesome interactive that shows how correlations between states differ between the FiveThirtyEight and Economist election models. This is an engaging and well-crafted visualization.

title: Does Palantir See Too Much?

Palantir helps governments and law enforcement decipher vast amounts of data — to mysterious and, some say, dangerous ends. This is a great profile of the secretive tech giant and its surprisingly lofty aims.

Get started with Mona for free today.

Feature stores are used to manage the datasets and pipelines that are needed to get machine learning applications to production. This post walks through the key components of a modern feature store and how they unlock a new kind of collaboration across data science teams.

Science.

title: A Platform Built to Increase Your Efficiencies by 85%
summary: To effectively label data for machine learning, you need a platform that can perform at the quality and scale you demand. Read how Alegion’s platform increases your efficiencies, quality, and scale.
